entities.name: WINDOWS MANAGEMENT INSTRUMENTATION
entities.description: Windows Management Instrumentation is an attack method that allows for remote management and monitoring of Windows systems, often exploited by attackers for malicious purposes.

entities.name: SCREEN CAPTURE
entities.description: Screen Capture is an attack method that involves taking screenshots of a user's display, often used for spying or data theft.

entities.name: BOOT OR LOGON INITIALIZATION SCRIPTS
entities.description: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts are attack methods that execute scripts during the boot or logon process, potentially allowing attackers to run malicious code.

entities.name: ADVERSARY-IN-THE-MIDDLE
entities.description: Adversary-in-the-Middle is an attack method where an attacker intercepts communication between two parties, often to steal information or manipulate data.

entities.name: EXTRA WINDOW MEMORY INJECTION
entities.description: Extra Window Memory Injection is an attack method that involves injecting code into the memory of a running process, allowing for unauthorized control or data access.

entities.name: SCHEDULED TASK
entities.description: Scheduled Task is an attack method that allows attackers to execute programs or scripts at specified times, often used to maintain persistence on a compromised system.

entities.name: SOFTWARE
entities.description: Software refers to various programs and applications that can be exploited or used in cyber attacks, including malware and legitimate tools.

entities.name: LOGON SCRIPT (WINDOWS)
entities.description: Logon Script (Windows) is a sub attack technique of Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts that runs scripts when a user logs into a Windows system.

entities.name: NETWORK LOGON SCRIPT
entities.description: Network Logon Script is a sub attack technique of Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts that executes scripts for network logon processes.

entities.name: STARTUP ITEMS
entities.description: Startup Items are sub attack techniques of Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts that run programs automatically when the system starts.

entities.name: LOGIN HOOK
entities.description: Login Hook is a sub attack technique of Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts that allows for custom actions during the login process.

entities.name: DHCP SPOOFING
entities.description: DHCP Spoofing is a sub attack technique of Adversary-in-the-Middle that involves sending false DHCP responses to clients.

entities.name: ARP CACHE POISONING
entities.description: ARP Cache Poisoning is a sub attack technique of Adversary-in-the-Middle that involves sending false ARP messages to associate the attacker's MAC address with the IP address of another host.

entities.name: LLMNR/NBT-NS POISONING AND SMB RELAY
entities.description: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay is a sub attack technique of Adversary-in-the-Middle that exploits the LLMNR and NBT-NS protocols to capture credentials.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a mitigation method for the Extra Window Memory Injection attack technique that aims to prevent malicious behavior on endpoints.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a mitigation method for the Scheduled Task and Windows Management Instrumentation attack techniques that involves managing and securing privileged accounts.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is a mitigation method for the Scheduled Task and Windows Management Instrumentation attack techniques that involves managing user accounts and their permissions.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a mitigation method for the Scheduled Task and Archive via Utility attack techniques that involves reviewing and monitoring system activities.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration is a mitigation method for the Scheduled Task attack technique that involves configuring the operating system to enhance security.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Filter Network Traffic is a mitigation method for the Socket Filters attack technique that involves controlling the flow of network traffic to prevent unauthorized access.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program is a mitigation method for the VNC attack technique that involves disabling or removing unnecessary features or programs to enhance security.

entities.name: LIMIT SOFTWARE INSTALLATION
entities.description: Limit Software Installation is a mitigation method for the VNC attack technique that restricts the installation of unauthorized software on systems.

entities.name: EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description: Execution Prevention is a mitigation method for the Windows Management Instrumentation attack technique that aims to prevent unauthorized code execution.

entities.name: BOOT OR LOGON INITIALIZATION SCRIPTS
entities.description: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts are attack techniques that execute scripts during the boot or logon process, potentially allowing unauthorized access.

entities.name: RC SCRIPTS
entities.description: RC Scripts are attack techniques that can be used to execute commands remotely, often used in cyber attacks.

entities.name: LOGON SCRIPT (WINDOWS)
entities.description: Logon Script (Windows) is an attack technique that executes scripts when a user logs into a Windows system, which can be exploited for malicious purposes.

entities.name: STARTUP ITEMS
entities.description: Startup Items are attack techniques that involve programs set to run automatically when the system starts, which can be exploited for malicious purposes.

entities.name: ADVERSARY-IN-THE-MIDDLE
entities.description: Adversary-in-the-Middle is an attack technique where an attacker intercepts communication between two parties, allowing for data theft or manipulation.

entities.name: LLMNR/NBT-NS POISONING AND SMB RELAY
entities.description: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay is an attack technique that exploits the Windows name resolution protocols to capture credentials and relay them to other systems.)<|COMPLETE|>

entities.name: NETWORK LOGON SCRIPT
entities.description: Network Logon Script is an attack technique that executes scripts over the network during user logon, which can be exploited for unauthorized access.

entities.name: LOGIN HOOK
entities.description: Login Hook is an attack technique that allows for the execution of code during the login process, potentially enabling unauthorized access.

entities.name: DHCP SPOOFING
entities.description: DHCP Spoofing is an attack technique where a malicious DHCP server provides false IP addresses to clients, leading to unauthorized access.

entities.name: ARP CACHE POISONING
entities.description: ARP Cache Poisoning is an attack technique that involves sending false ARP messages to a local area network, allowing an attacker to intercept traffic.

chunk:
The following content describes information about the attack technique. The format of each attack technique's information is as follows:
Attack technique name: ***
Attack technique description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the attack technique, a detailed description, and the platforms it can target.

Attack technique name: VNC
Attck technique description: Adversaries may use [Valid Accounts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078) to remotely control machines using Virtual Network Computing (VNC).  VNC is a platform-independent desktop sharing system that uses the RFB (“remote framebuffer”) protocol to enable users to remotely control another computer’s display by relaying the screen, mouse, and keyboard inputs over the network.(Citation: The Remote Framebuffer Protocol)

VNC differs from [Remote Desktop Protocol](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/001) as VNC is screen-sharing software rather than resource-sharing software. By default, VNC uses the system's authentication, but it can be configured to use credentials specific to VNC.(Citation: MacOS VNC software for Remote Desktop)(Citation: VNC Authentication)

Adversaries may abuse VNC to perform malicious actions as the logged-on user such as opening documents, downloading files, and running arbitrary commands. An adversary could use VNC to remotely control and monitor a system to collect data and information to pivot to other systems within the network. Specific VNC libraries/implementations have also been susceptible to brute force attacks and memory usage exploitation.(Citation: Hijacking VNC)(Citation: macOS root VNC login without authentication)(Citation: VNC Vulnerabilities)(Citation: Offensive Security VNC Authentication Check)(Citation: Attacking VNC Servers PentestLab)(Citation: Havana authentication bug)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Attack technique name: Fileless Storage
Attck technique description: Adversaries may store data in "fileless" formats to conceal malicious activity from defenses. Fileless storage can be broadly defined as any format other than a file. Common examples of non-volatile fileless storage include the Windows Registry, event logs, or WMI repository.(Citation: Microsoft Fileless)(Citation: SecureList Fileless)

Similar to fileless in-memory behaviors such as [Reflective Code Loading](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1620) and [Process Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055), fileless data storage may remain undetected by anti-virus and other endpoint security tools that can only access specific file formats from disk storage.

Adversaries may use fileless storage to conceal various types of stored data, including payloads/shellcode (potentially being used as part of [Persistence](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0003)) and collected data not yet exfiltrated from the victim (e.g., [Local Data Staging](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1074/001)). Adversaries also often encrypt, encode, splice, or otherwise obfuscate this fileless data when stored.

Some forms of fileless storage activity may indirectly create artifacts in the file system, but in central and otherwise difficult to inspect formats such as the WMI (e.g., `%SystemRoot%\System32\Wbem\Repository`) or Registry (e.g., `%SystemRoot%\System32\Config`) physical files.(Citation: Microsoft Fileless) 
Platforms: Windows

Attack technique name: ARP Cache Poisoning
Attck technique description: Adversaries may poison Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) caches to position themselves between the communication of two or more networked devices. This activity may be used to enable follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002).

The ARP protocol is used to resolve IPv4 addresses to link layer addresses, such as a media access control (MAC) address.(Citation: RFC826 ARP) Devices in a local network segment communicate with each other by using link layer addresses. If a networked device does not have the link layer address of a particular networked device, it may send out a broadcast ARP request to the local network to translate the IP address to a MAC address. The device with the associated IP address directly replies with its MAC address. The networked device that made the ARP request will then use as well as store that information in its ARP cache.

An adversary may passively wait for an ARP request to poison the ARP cache of the requesting device. The adversary may reply with their MAC address, thus deceiving the victim by making them believe that they are communicating with the intended networked device. For the adversary to poison the ARP cache, their reply must be faster than the one made by the legitimate IP address owner. Adversaries may also send a gratuitous ARP reply that maliciously announces the ownership of a particular IP address to all the devices in the local network segment.

The ARP protocol is stateless and does not require authentication. Therefore, devices may wrongly add or update the MAC address of the IP address in their ARP cache.(Citation: Sans ARP Spoofing Aug 2003)(Citation: Cylance Cleaver)

Adversaries may use ARP cache poisoning as a means to intercept network traffic. This activity may be used to collect and/or relay data such as credentials, especially those sent over an insecure, unencrypted protocol.(Citation: Sans ARP Spoofing Aug 2003)

Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Attack technique name: Adversary-in-the-Middle
Attck technique description: Adversaries may attempt to position themselves between two or more networked devices using an adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) technique

entities.name: VNC
entities.description: VNC is a remote desktop sharing system that allows users to control another computer's display over a network using the RFB protocol.

entities.name: FILELESS STORAGE
entities.description: Fileless storage refers to storing data in non-file formats to evade detection by security tools, often used by adversaries to conceal malicious activities.

entities.name: ARP CACHE POISONING
entities.description: ARP Cache Poisoning is a technique where adversaries manipulate ARP caches to intercept network traffic between devices.

entities.name: ADVERSARY-IN-THE-MIDDLE
entities.description: Adversary-in-the-Middle is a technique where adversaries position themselves between two or more networked devices to intercept or manipulate communications.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform that can be targeted by various attack techniques including VNC, ARP Cache Poisoning, and Fileless Storage.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that can be targeted by various attack techniques including VNC, ARP Cache Poisoning, and Fileless Storage.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that can be targeted by various attack techniques including VNC, Fileless Storage, and ARP Cache Poisoning.

entities.name: REMOTE DESKTOP PROTOCOL
entities.description: Remote Desktop Protocol is a Microsoft protocol that allows users to connect to another computer over a network, differing from VNC in its resource-sharing capabilities.

entities.name: RFB
entities.description: RFB, or Remote Framebuffer, is the protocol used by VNC to transmit screen updates and input events between the client and server.

entities.name: WINDOWS REGISTRY
entities.description: The Windows Registry is a hierarchical database used by Windows to store configuration settings and options, often targeted in fileless storage techniques.

entities.name: EVENT LOGS
entities.description: Event logs are records of events occurring within an operating system or software, which can be used for fileless storage to conceal malicious activities.

entities.name: WMI REPOSITORY
entities.description: WMI Repository is a database that stores management information and is used in Windows for fileless storage techniques.

entities.name: REFLECTIVE CODE LOADING
entities.description: Reflective Code Loading is a technique used to execute code directly in memory without writing it to disk, often associated with fileless attacks.

entities.name: PROCESS INJECTION
entities.description: Process Injection is a technique where an adversary injects code into the address space of another process to execute malicious actions, related to fileless storage.

entities.name: CREDENTIALS
entities.description: Credentials refer to the authentication information used to verify a user's identity, often targeted in ARP Cache Poisoning and other attacks.

entities.name: MAC ADDRESS
entities.description: A MAC Address is a unique identifier assigned to network interfaces for communications on the physical network segment, relevant in ARP Cache Poisoning.

entities.name: IP ADDRESS
entities.description: An IP Address is a numerical label assigned to each device connected to a computer network that uses the Internet Protocol for communication, relevant in ARP Cache Poisoning.

entities.name: UNENCRYPTED PROTOCOL
entities.description: Unencrypted protocols are communication protocols that do not use encryption, making them vulnerable to interception in attacks like ARP Cache Poisoning.)<|COMPLETE|>

cache poisoning as a means to intercept network traffic. This activity may be used to collect and/or relay data such as credentials, especially those sent over an insecure, unencrypted protocol.(Citation: Sans ARP Spoofing Aug 2003)

Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Attack technique name: Adversary-in-the-Middle
Attck technique description: Adversaries may attempt to position themselves between two or more networked devices using an adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) technique to support follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040), [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002), or replay attacks ([Exploitation for Credential Access](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1212)). By abusing features of common networking protocols that can determine the flow of network traffic (e.g. ARP, DNS, LLMNR, etc.), adversaries may force a device to communicate through an adversary controlled system so they can collect information or perform additional actions.(Citation: Rapid7 MiTM Basics)

For example, adversaries may manipulate victim DNS settings to enable other malicious activities such as preventing/redirecting users from accessing legitimate sites and/or pushing additional malware.(Citation: ttint_rat)(Citation: dns_changer_trojans)(Citation: ad_blocker_with_miner) Adversaries may also manipulate DNS and leverage their position in order to intercept user credentials, including access tokens ([Steal Application Access Token](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1528)) and session cookies ([Steal Web Session Cookie](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1539)).(Citation: volexity_0day_sophos_FW)(Citation: Token tactics) [Downgrade Attack](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/010)s can also be used to establish an AiTM position, such as by negotiating a less secure, deprecated, or weaker version of communication protocol (SSL/TLS) or encryption algorithm.(Citation: mitm_tls_downgrade_att)(Citation: taxonomy_downgrade_att_tls)(Citation: tlseminar_downgrade_att)

Adversaries may also leverage the AiTM position to attempt to monitor and/or modify traffic, such as in [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). Adversaries can setup a position similar to AiTM to prevent traffic from flowing to the appropriate destination, potentially to [Impair Defenses](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562) and/or in support of a [Network Denial of Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1498).
Platforms: Windows, macOS, Linux, Network

Attack technique name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Attck technique description: Adversaries may abuse Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to execute malicious commands and payloads. WMI is designed for programmers and is the infrastructure for management data and operations on Windows systems.(Citation: WMI 1-3) WMI is an administration feature that provides a uniform environment to access Windows system components.

The WMI service enables both local and remote access, though the latter is facilitated by [Remote Services](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021) such as [Distributed Component Object Model](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/003) and [Windows Remote Management](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/006).(Citation: WMI 1-3) Remote WMI over DCOM operates using port 135, whereas WMI over WinRM operates over port 5985 when using HTTP and 5986 for HTTPS.(Citation: WMI 1-3) (Citation: Mandiant WMI)

An adversary can use WMI to interact with local and remote systems and use it as a means to execute various behaviors, such as gathering information for [Discovery](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0007) as well as [Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0002) of commands and payloads.(Citation: Mandiant WMI) For example, `wmic.exe` can be abused by an adversary to delete shadow copies with the command `wmic.exe Shadowcopy Delete` (i.e., [Inhibit System Recovery](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1490)).(Citation: WMI 6)

**Note:** `wmic.exe` is deprecated as of January of 2024, with the WMIC feature being “disabled by default” on Windows 11+. WMIC will be removed from subsequent Windows releases and replaced by [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) as the primary WMI interface.(Citation: WMI 7,8) In addition to PowerShell and tools like `wbemtool.exe`, COM APIs can also be used to programmatically interact with WMI via C++, .NET, VBScript, etc.(Citation: WMI 7,8)
Platforms: Windows

Attack technique name: Extra Window Memory Injection
Attck technique description: Adversaries may inject malicious code into process via Extra Window Memory (EWM) in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. EWM injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.

entities.name: CACHE POISONING
entities.description: Cache poisoning is a technique used to intercept network traffic, potentially collecting sensitive data such as credentials over insecure protocols.

entities.name: ADVERSARY-IN-THE-MIDDLE
entities.description: Adversary-in-the-Middle (AiTM) is a technique where adversaries position themselves between networked devices to intercept or manipulate data.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system platform that supports various attack techniques.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is a widely used operating system that can be targeted by various attack techniques, including WMI abuse.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system developed by Apple that is also susceptible to various attack techniques.

entities.name: WMI
entities.description: Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) is a feature in Windows that allows for management data and operations on Windows systems, which can be abused by adversaries.

entities.name: EXTRA WINDOW MEMORY INJECTION
entities.description: Extra Window Memory Injection is a technique used by adversaries to inject malicious code into processes to evade defenses and potentially elevate privileges.

entities.name: TRANSMITTED DATA MANIPULATION
entities.description: Transmitted Data Manipulation is a technique where adversaries alter data being transmitted over a network to achieve malicious objectives.

entities.name: REPLAY ATTACKS
entities.description: Replay Attacks involve capturing and retransmitting valid data transmissions to deceive systems or users.

entities.name: CREDENTIAL ACCESS
entities.description: Credential Access techniques are methods used by adversaries to obtain sensitive information such as usernames and passwords.

entities.name: SSL/TLS
entities.description: SSL/TLS are cryptographic protocols designed to provide secure communication over a computer network, which can be targeted in downgrade attacks.

entities.name: POWER SHELL
entities.description: PowerShell is a task automation and configuration management framework from Microsoft, which can be used to interact with WMI.

chunk: process via Extra Window Memory (EWM) in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges. EWM injection is a method of executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process. Before creating a window, graphical Windows-based processes must prescribe to or register a windows class, which stipulate appearance and behavior (via windows procedures, which are functions that handle input/output of data).(Citation: Microsoft Window Classes) Registration of new windows classes can include a request for up to 40 bytes of EWM to be appended to the allocated memory of each instance of that class. This EWM is intended to store data specific to that window and has specific application programming interface (API) functions to set and get its value. (Citation: Microsoft GetWindowLong function) (Citation: Microsoft SetWindowLong function) Although small, the EWM is large enough to store a 32-bit pointer and is often used to point to a windows procedure. Malware may possibly utilize this memory location in part of an attack chain that includes writing code to shared sections of the process’s memory, placing a pointer to the code in EWM, then invoking execution by returning execution control to the address in the process’s EWM. Execution granted through EWM injection may allow access to both the target process's memory and possibly elevated privileges. Writing payloads to shared sections also avoids the use of highly monitored API calls such as WriteProcessMemory and CreateRemoteThread.(Citation: Elastic Process Injection July 2017) More sophisticated malware samples may also potentially bypass protection mechanisms such as data execution prevention (DEP) by triggering a combination of windows procedures and other system functions that will rewrite the malicious payload inside an executable portion of the target process. (Citation: MalwareTech Power Loader Aug 2013) (Citation: WeLiveSecurity Gapz and Redyms Mar 2013) Running code in the context of another process may allow access to the process's memory, system/network resources, and possibly elevated privileges. Execution via EWM injection may also evade detection from security products since the execution is masked under a legitimate process. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts Attck technique description: Adversaries may use scripts automatically executed at boot or logon initialization to establish persistence.(Citation: Mandiant APT29 Eye Spy Email Nov 22)(Citation: Anomali Rocke March 2019) Initialization scripts can be used to perform administrative functions, which may often execute other programs or send information to an internal logging server. These scripts can vary based on operating system and whether applied locally or remotely. Adversaries may use these scripts to maintain persistence on a single system. Depending on the access configuration of the logon scripts, either local credentials or an administrator account may be necessary. An adversary may also be able to escalate their privileges since some boot or logon initialization scripts run with higher privileges. Platforms: macOS, Windows, Linux, Network Attack technique name: RC Scripts Attck technique description: Adversaries may establish persistence by modifying RC scripts which are executed during a Unix-like system’s startup. These files allow system administrators to map and start custom services at startup for different run levels. RC scripts require root privileges to modify. Adversaries can establish persistence by adding a malicious binary path or shell commands to rc.local, rc.common, and other RC scripts specific to the Unix-like distribution.(Citation: IranThreats Kittens Dec 2017)(Citation: Intezer HiddenWasp Map 2019) Upon reboot, the system executes the script's contents as root, resulting in persistence. Adversary abuse of RC scripts is especially effective for lightweight Unix-like distributions using the root user as default, such as IoT or embedded systems.(Citation: intezer-kaiji-malware) Several Unix-like systems have moved to Systemd and deprecated the use of RC scripts. This is now a deprecated mechanism in macOS in favor of [Launchd](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053/004). (Citation: Apple Developer Doco Archive Launchd)(Citation: Startup Items) This technique can be used on Mac OS X Panther v10.3 and earlier versions which still execute the RC scripts.(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence) To maintain backwards compatibility some systems, such as Ubuntu, will execute the RC scripts if they exist with the correct file permissions.(Citation: Ubuntu Manpage systemd rc) Platforms: macOS, Linux, Network Attack technique name: Logon Script (Windows) Attck technique description: Adversaries may use Windows logon scripts automatically executed at logon initialization to establish persistence. Windows allows logon scripts to be run whenever a specific user or group of users log into a system.(Citation: TechNet Logon Scripts) This is done via adding a path to a script to the HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript Registry key.(Citation: Hexacorn Logon Scripts) Adversaries may use these scripts to maintain persistence on a single system. Depending on the access configuration of the logon scripts, either local credentials or an administrator account may be necessary. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Screen Capture Attck technique description: Adversaries may attempt to take screen captures of the desktop to gather information over the course of an operation. Screen capturing functionality may be included as a feature of a remote access tool used in post-compromise operations. Taking a screenshot is also typically possible through native utilities or API calls, such as CopyFromScreen, xwd, or screencapture.(Citation

entities.name: EXTRA WINDOW MEMORY
entities.description: Extra Window Memory (EWM) is a method used to evade process-based defenses and potentially elevate privileges by executing arbitrary code in the address space of a separate live process.

entities.name: MICROSOFT

entities.name: ELASTIC

entities.name: MALWARETECH
entities.description: MalwareTech is a cybersecurity research group known for analyzing and reporting on malware threats and vulnerabilities.

entities.name: IRANTHREATS

entities.description: Ubuntu is a popular Linux distribution known for its ease of use and community support, often used in personal and enterprise environments.

entities.name: DATA EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description: Data Execution Prevention (DEP) is a security feature that helps prevent code execution from non-executable memory regions, often targeted by malware.

entities.name: BOOT OR LOGON INITIALIZATION SCRIPTS
entities.description: Boot or logon initialization scripts are scripts that run automatically at system startup or user logon, potentially used by adversaries to establish persistence.

entities.name: RC SCRIPTS
entities.description: RC scripts are scripts executed during the startup of Unix-like systems, allowing administrators to map and start custom services, which can be exploited for persistence.

entities.name: LOGON SCRIPT
entities.description: Logon scripts in Windows are automatically executed at user logon, which can be manipulated by adversaries to maintain persistence on a system.

chunk: Attack technique name: Screen Capture Attck technique description: Adversaries may attempt to take screen captures of the desktop to gather information over the course of an operation. Screen capturing functionality may be included as a feature of a remote access tool used in post-compromise operations. Taking a screenshot is also typically possible through native utilities or API calls, such as CopyFromScreen, xwd, or screencapture.(Citation: CopyFromScreen .NET)(Citation: Antiquated Mac Malware) Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows Attack technique name: Scheduled Task Attck technique description: Adversaries may abuse the Windows Task Scheduler to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution of malicious code. There are multiple ways to access the Task Scheduler in Windows. The [schtasks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0111) utility can be run directly on the command line, or the Task Scheduler can be opened through the GUI within the Administrator Tools section of the Control Panel. In some cases, adversaries have used a .NET wrapper for the Windows Task Scheduler, and alternatively, adversaries have used the Windows netapi32 library to create a scheduled task. The deprecated [at](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0110) utility could also be abused by adversaries (ex: [At](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1053/002)), though at.exe can not access tasks created with schtasks or the Control Panel. An adversary may use Windows Task Scheduler to execute programs at system startup or on a scheduled basis for persistence. The Windows Task Scheduler can also be abused to conduct remote Execution as part of Lateral Movement and/or to run a process under the context of a specified account (such as SYSTEM). Similar to [System Binary Proxy Execution](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218), adversaries have also abused the Windows Task Scheduler to potentially mask one-time execution under signed/trusted system processes.(Citation: ProofPoint Serpent) Adversaries may also create "hidden" scheduled tasks (i.e. [Hide Artifacts](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1564)) that may not be visible to defender tools and manual queries used to enumerate tasks. Specifically, an adversary may hide a task from `schtasks /query` and the Task Scheduler by deleting the associated Security Descriptor (SD) registry value (where deletion of this value must be completed using SYSTEM permissions).(Citation: SigmaHQ)(Citation: Tarrask scheduled task) Adversaries may also employ alternate methods to hide tasks, such as altering the metadata (e.g., `Index` value) within associated registry keys.(Citation: Defending Against Scheduled Task Attacks in Windows Environments) Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Archive via Utility Attck technique description: Adversaries may use utilities to compress and/or encrypt collected data prior to exfiltration. Many utilities include functionalities to compress, encrypt, or otherwise package data into a format that is easier/more secure to transport. Adversaries may abuse various utilities to compress or encrypt data before exfiltration. Some third party utilities may be preinstalled, such as tar on Linux and macOS or zip on Windows systems. On Windows, diantz or makecab may be used to package collected files into a cabinet (.cab) file. diantz may also be used to download and compress files from remote locations (i.e. [Remote Data Staging](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1074/002)).(Citation: diantz.exe_lolbas) xcopy on Windows can copy files and directories with a variety of options. Additionally, adversaries may use [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160) to Base64 encode collected data before exfiltration. Adversaries may use also third party utilities, such as 7-Zip, WinRAR, and WinZip, to perform similar activities.(Citation: 7zip Homepage)(Citation: WinRAR Homepage)(Citation: WinZip Homepage) Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows Attack technique name: Network Logon Script Attck technique description: Adversaries may use network logon scripts automatically executed at logon initialization to establish persistence. Network logon scripts can be assigned using Active Directory or Group Policy Objects.(Citation: Petri Logon Script AD) These logon scripts run with the privileges of the user they are assigned to. Depending on the systems within the network, initializing one of these scripts could apply to more than one or potentially all systems. Adversaries may use these scripts to maintain persistence on a network. Depending on the access configuration of the logon scripts, either local credentials or an administrator account may be necessary. Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: DHCP Spoofing Attck technique description: Adversaries may redirect network traffic to adversary-owned systems by spoofing Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) traffic and acting as a malicious DHCP server on the victim network. By achieving the adversary-in-the-middle (AiTM) position, adversaries may collect network communications, including passed credentials, especially those sent over insecure, unencrypted protocols. This may also enable follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). DHCP is based on a client-server model and has two functionalities: a protocol for providing network configuration settings from a DHCP server

entities.name: SCREEN CAPTURE
entities.description: Screen Capture is an attack technique where adversaries take screenshots of the desktop to gather information during an operation.

entities.name: SCHEDULED TASK
entities.description: Scheduled Task is an attack technique where adversaries abuse the Windows Task Scheduler to execute malicious code at scheduled times.

entities.name: ARCHIVE VIA UTILITY
entities.description: Archive via Utility is an attack technique where adversaries use utilities to compress or encrypt data before exfiltration.

entities.name: NETWORK LOGON SCRIPT
entities.description: Network Logon Script is an attack technique where adversaries use scripts executed at logon to establish persistence on a network.

entities.name: DHCP SPOOFING
entities.description: DHCP Spoofing is an attack technique where adversaries redirect network traffic by spoofing DHCP traffic to act as a malicious DHCP server.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an operating system platform that supports various attack techniques such as Screen Capture and Archive via Utility.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system platform that supports various attack techniques such as Screen Capture and Archive via Utility.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system platform that supports various attack techniques such as Scheduled Task, Network Logon Script, and DHCP Spoofing.

entities.name: XWD
entities.description: xwd is a utility on Unix-like systems that can be used to capture screenshots, relevant to the Screen Capture attack technique.

entities.name: SCREENCAPTURE
entities.description: screencapture is a command-line utility on macOS that allows users to take screenshots, relevant to the Screen Capture attack technique.

entities.name: SCHTASKS
entities.description: schtasks is a command-line utility in Windows that allows users to create, delete, configure, or display scheduled tasks, relevant to the Scheduled Task attack technique.

entities.name: AT
entities.description: at is a deprecated command-line utility in Windows that was used to schedule tasks, relevant to the Scheduled Task attack technique.

entities.name: DIANTZ
entities.description: diantz is a utility on Windows that can be used to package and compress files, relevant to the Archive via Utility attack technique.

entities.name: MAKECAB
entities.description: makecab is a Windows utility that creates cabinet (.cab) files, relevant to the Archive via Utility attack technique.

entities.name: CERTUTIL
entities.description: certutil is a command-line utility in Windows that can be used to encode data in Base64, relevant to the Archive via Utility attack technique.

entities.name: TAR
entities.description: tar is a utility on Linux and macOS used for compressing and archiving files, relevant to the Archive via Utility attack technique.

entities.name: ZIP
entities.description: zip is a utility on Windows that compresses files, relevant to the Archive via Utility attack technique.

entities.name: 7-ZIP
entities.description: 7-Zip is a third-party utility that can compress and encrypt files, relevant to the Archive via Utility attack technique.

entities.name: WINRAR
entities.description: WinRAR is a third-party utility that can compress and encrypt files, relevant to the Archive via Utility attack technique.

entities.name: WINZIP
entities.description: WinZip is a third-party utility that can compress and encrypt files, relevant to the Archive via Utility attack technique.

entities.name: ACTIVE DIRECTORY
entities.description: Active Directory is a directory service for Windows domain networks that can be used to assign network logon scripts, relevant to the Network Logon Script attack technique.

entities.name: GROUP POLICY OBJECTS
entities.description: Group Policy Objects are used in Windows to manage user and computer settings, including the assignment of network logon scripts, relevant to the Network Logon Script attack technique.

entities.name: DYNAMIC HOST CONFIGURATION PROTOCOL
entities.description: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) is a network management protocol used to automate the process of configuring devices on IP networks, relevant to the DHCP Spoofing attack technique.)<|COMPLETE|>

chunk: TM) position, adversaries may collect network communications, including passed credentials, especially those sent over insecure, unencrypted protocols. This may also enable follow-on behaviors such as [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1565/002). DHCP is based on a client-server model and has two functionalities: a protocol for providing network configuration settings from a DHCP server to a client and a mechanism for allocating network addresses to clients.(Citation: rfc2131) The typical server-client interaction is as follows: 1. The client broadcasts a `DISCOVER` message. 2. The server responds with an `OFFER` message, which includes an available network address. 3. The client broadcasts a `REQUEST` message, which includes the network address offered. 4. The server acknowledges with an `ACK` message and the client receives the network configuration parameters. Adversaries may spoof as a rogue DHCP server on the victim network, from which legitimate hosts may receive malicious network configurations. For example, malware can act as a DHCP server and provide adversary-owned DNS servers to the victimized computers.(Citation: new_rogue_DHCP_serv_malware)(Citation: w32.tidserv.g) Through the malicious network configurations, an adversary may achieve the AiTM position, route client traffic through adversary-controlled systems, and collect information from the client network. DHCPv6 clients can receive network configuration information without being assigned an IP address by sending a INFORMATION-REQUEST (code 11) message to the All_DHCP_Relay_Agents_and_Servers multicast address.(Citation: rfc3315) Adversaries may use their rogue DHCP server to respond to this request message with malicious network configurations. Rather than establishing an AiTM position, adversaries may also abuse DHCP spoofing to perform a DHCP exhaustion attack (i.e, [Service Exhaustion Flood](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1499/002)) by generating many broadcast DISCOVER messages to exhaust a network’s DHCP allocation pool. Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS Attack technique name: LLMNR/NBT-NS Poisoning and SMB Relay Attck technique description: By responding to LLMNR/NBT-NS network traffic, adversaries may spoof an authoritative source for name resolution to force communication with an adversary controlled system. This activity may be used to collect or relay authentication materials. Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution (LLMNR) and NetBIOS Name Service (NBT-NS) are Microsoft Windows components that serve as alternate methods of host identification. LLMNR is based upon the Domain Name System (DNS) format and allows hosts on the same local link to perform name resolution for other hosts. NBT-NS identifies systems on a local network by their NetBIOS name. (Citation: Wikipedia LLMNR)(Citation: TechNet NetBIOS) Adversaries can spoof an authoritative source for name resolution on a victim network by responding to LLMNR (UDP 5355)/NBT-NS (UDP 137) traffic as if they know the identity of the requested host, effectively poisoning the service so that the victims will communicate with the adversary controlled system. If the requested host belongs to a resource that requires identification/authentication, the username and NTLMv2 hash will then be sent to the adversary controlled system. The adversary can then collect the hash information sent over the wire through tools that monitor the ports for traffic or through [Network Sniffing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1040) and crack the hashes offline through [Brute Force](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1110) to obtain the plaintext passwords. In some cases where an adversary has access to a system that is in the authentication path between systems or when automated scans that use credentials attempt to authenticate to an adversary controlled system, the NTLMv1/v2 hashes can be intercepted and relayed to access and execute code against a target system. The relay step can happen in conjunction with poisoning but may also be independent of it.(Citation: byt3bl33d3r NTLM Relaying)(Citation: Secure Ideas SMB Relay) Additionally, adversaries may encapsulate the NTLMv1/v2 hashes into various protocols, such as LDAP, SMB, MSSQL and HTTP, to expand and use multiple services with the valid NTLM response.  Several tools may be used to poison name services within local networks such as NBNSpoof, Metasploit, and [Responder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0174).(Citation: GitHub NBNSpoof)(Citation: Rapid7 LLMNR Spoofer)(Citation: GitHub Responder) Platforms: Windows Attack technique name: Socket Filters Attck technique description: Adversaries may attach filters to a network socket to monitor then activate backdoors used for persistence or command and control. With elevated permissions, adversaries can use features such as the `libpcap` library to open sockets and install filters to allow or disallow certain types of data to come through the socket. The filter may apply to all traffic passing through the specified network interface (or every interface if not specified). When the network interface receives a packet matching the filter criteria, additional actions can be triggered on the host, such as activation of a reverse shell. To establish a connection, an adversary sends a crafted packet to the targeted host that matches the installed filter criteria.(Citation: haking9 libpcap network sniffing) Adversaries have used these socket filters to trigger the installation of implants, conduct ping backs, and to invoke command shells. Communication with these socket filters may also be used

entities.name: DHCP
entities.description: DHCP is a protocol used for providing network configuration settings from a DHCP server to a client and allocating network addresses to clients.

entities.name: LLMNR
entities.description: Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution (LLMNR) is a Microsoft Windows component that allows hosts on the same local link to perform name resolution for other hosts.

entities.name: NBT-NS
entities.description: NetBIOS Name Service (NBT-NS) is a Microsoft Windows component that identifies systems on a local network by their NetBIOS name.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is an operating system developed by Microsoft that includes components like LLMNR and NBT-NS for network communication.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system that can be used in various computing environments, including network configurations.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system developed by Apple Inc. that is used on Macintosh computers and supports various network functionalities.

entities.name: METASPLOIT
entities.description: Metasploit is a penetration testing framework that can be used to exploit vulnerabilities in systems, including poisoning name services.

entities.name: RESPONDER
entities.description: Responder is a tool used for network attacks that can poison name services within local networks.

entities.name: NBNSPOOF
entities.description: NBNSpoof is a tool that can be used to spoof NetBIOS name service requests in local networks.

entities.name: TRANSMITTED DATA MANIPULATION
entities.description: Transmitted data manipulation refers to the act of altering data packets as they are transmitted over a network, potentially leading to unauthorized access or data breaches.

entities.name: DHCP EXHAUSTION ATTACK
entities.description: A DHCP exhaustion attack is a type of denial-of-service attack where an adversary generates numerous DHCP requests to exhaust the available IP address pool, preventing legitimate clients from obtaining network access.

entities.name: AI-TM POSITION
entities.description: The AiTM position refers to an adversarial tactic where attackers position themselves to intercept and manipulate network traffic, often to collect sensitive information.

entities.name: AUTHENTICATION MATERIALS
entities.description: Authentication materials include credentials such as usernames and passwords that are used to verify the identity of users in a network.

entities.name: NTLMV2 HASH
entities.description: NTLMv2 hash is a cryptographic representation of a password used in Windows authentication, which can be intercepted and exploited by adversaries.

entities.name: REVERSE SHELL
entities.description: A reverse shell is a type of shell where the target machine opens a connection to an attacker's machine, allowing the attacker to execute commands remotely.

entities.name: SOCKET FILTERS
entities.description: Socket filters are mechanisms that allow monitoring and controlling the data passing through network sockets, often used by adversaries for persistence and command and control.

can include NTLMv2 hashes that are intercepted during network communications.</data>      <data key="d5">ad4b9611d8e6fbd36d902b1e0c20803a</data>    </edge>    <edge source="REVERSE SHELL" target="SOCKET FILTERS">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">A reverse shell can be triggered by socket filters that monitor network traffic and execute commands based on specific criteria.</data>      <data key="d5">ad4b9611d8e6fbd36d902b1e0c20803a</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

chunk: specified). When the network interface receives a packet matching the filter criteria, additional actions can be triggered on the host, such as activation of a reverse shell. To establish a connection, an adversary sends a crafted packet to the targeted host that matches the installed filter criteria.(Citation: haking9 libpcap network sniffing) Adversaries have used these socket filters to trigger the installation of implants, conduct ping backs, and to invoke command shells. Communication with these socket filters may also be used in conjunction with [Protocol Tunneling](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1572).(Citation: exatrack bpf filters passive backdoors)(Citation: Leonardo Turla Penquin May 2020) Filters can be installed on any Unix-like platform with `libpcap` installed or on Windows hosts using `Winpcap`. Adversaries may use either `libpcap` with `pcap_setfilter` or the standard library function `setsockopt` with `SO_ATTACH_FILTER` options. Since the socket connection is not active until the packet is received, this behavior may be difficult to detect due to the lack of activity on a host, low CPU overhead, and limited visibility into raw socket usage. Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows Attack technique name: Login Hook Attck technique description: Adversaries may use a Login Hook to establish persistence executed upon user logon. A login hook is a plist file that points to a specific script to execute with root privileges upon user logon. The plist file is located in the /Library/Preferences/com.apple.loginwindow.plist file and can be modified using the defaults command-line utility. This behavior is the same for logout hooks where a script can be executed upon user logout. All hooks require administrator permissions to modify or create hooks.(Citation: Login Scripts Apple Dev)(Citation: LoginWindowScripts Apple Dev) Adversaries can add or insert a path to a malicious script in the com.apple.loginwindow.plist file, using the LoginHook or LogoutHook key-value pair. The malicious script is executed upon the next user login. If a login hook already exists, adversaries can add additional commands to an existing login hook. There can be only one login and logout hook on a system at a time.(Citation: S1 macOs Persistence)(Citation: Wardle Persistence Chapter) **Note:** Login hooks were deprecated in 10.11 version of macOS in favor of [Launch Daemon](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/004) and [Launch Agent](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/001) Platforms: macOS Attack technique name: Startup Items Attck technique description: Adversaries may use startup items automatically executed at boot initialization to establish persistence. Startup items execute during the final phase of the boot process and contain shell scripts or other executable files along with configuration information used by the system to determine the execution order for all startup items.(Citation: Startup Items) This is technically a deprecated technology (superseded by [Launch Daemon](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/004)), and thus the appropriate folder, /Library/StartupItems isn’t guaranteed to exist on the system by default, but does appear to exist by default on macOS Sierra. A startup item is a directory whose executable and configuration property list (plist), StartupParameters.plist, reside in the top-level directory. An adversary can create the appropriate folders/files in the StartupItems directory to register their own persistence mechanism.(Citation: Methods of Mac Malware Persistence) Additionally, since StartupItems run during the bootup phase of macOS, they will run as the elevated root user. Platforms: macOS

entities.name: LIBPCAP
entities.description: Libpcap is a widely used library for network packet capture and analysis on Unix-like operating systems.

entities.name: WINPCAP
entities.description: Winpcap is a Windows port of the libpcap library, used for network packet capture and analysis.

entities.name: MACOS
entities.description: macOS is an operating system developed by Apple Inc. for Macintosh computers, which supports various network functionalities.

entities.name: LINUX
entities.description: Linux is an open-source operating system that supports various network functionalities and tools like libpcap.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is a widely used operating system developed by Microsoft, which supports network packet capture through Winpcap.

entities.name: LOGIN HOOK
entities.description: Login Hook is a technique used to execute scripts with root privileges upon user logon in macOS.

entities.name: STARTUP ITEMS
entities.description: Startup Items are scripts or executable files that run automatically during the boot process in macOS to establish persistence.

entities.name: SCRIPT
entities.description: A script is a set of instructions executed by a computer program, often used for automation or to perform specific tasks.

entities.name: PLIST FILE
entities.description: A plist file is a property list file used in macOS to store serialized objects, often used for configuration settings.

entities.name: COMMAND-LINE UTILITY
entities.description: A command-line utility is a program that can be run from the command line interface to perform specific tasks or operations.

entities.name: MALICIOUS SCRIPT
entities.description: A malicious script is a script designed to perform harmful actions on a computer system, often used by adversaries to gain unauthorized access or control.

entities.name: LAUNCH DAEMON
entities.description: A Launch Daemon is a macOS service that runs in the background and can be used to execute scripts or programs at system startup or at specified intervals.

entities.name: LAUNCH AGENT
entities.description: A Launch Agent is a macOS service that runs in the context of a user and can be used to execute scripts or programs when a user logs in.

chunk:
The following content describes information about mitigation methods. The format of each mitigation method's information is as follows:
Mitigation method name: ***
Mitigation method description: ***
These respectively represent the name of the mitigation method and a detailed description of how it works.

Mitigation method name: User Training
Mitigation method description: Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

Mitigation method name: Privileged Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.

Mitigation method name: Network Intrusion Prevention
Mitigation method description: Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.

Mitigation method name: Encrypt Sensitive Information
Mitigation method description: Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.

Mitigation method name: Operating System Configuration
Mitigation method description: Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.

Mitigation method name: Limit Software Installation
Mitigation method description: Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.

Mitigation method name: Restrict File and Directory Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.

Mitigation method name: Restrict Registry Permissions
Mitigation method description: Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

Mitigation method name: Audit
Mitigation method description: Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.

Mitigation method name: Network Segmentation
Mitigation method description: Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.

Mitigation method name: Filter Network Traffic
Mitigation method description: Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

Mitigation method name: User Account Management
Mitigation method description: Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.

Mitigation method name: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint
Mitigation method description: Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.

Mitigation method name: Disable or Remove Feature or Program
Mitigation method description: Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.

Mitigation method name: Execution Prevention
Mitigation method description: Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.

Mitigation method name: Limit Access to Resource Over Network
Mitigation method description: Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.

entities.name: USER TRAINING
entities.description: User Training is a mitigation method aimed at educating users about security threats to reduce risks associated with spearphishing and social engineering.

entities.name: PRIVILEGED ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: Privileged Account Management is a method for overseeing the creation, modification, and permissions of privileged accounts to enhance security.

entities.name: NETWORK INTRUSION PREVENTION
entities.description: Network Intrusion Prevention involves using detection signatures to block unauthorized traffic at network boundaries.

entities.name: ENCRYPT SENSITIVE INFORMATION
entities.description: Encrypt Sensitive Information is a method that protects sensitive data through strong encryption techniques.

entities.name: OPERATING SYSTEM CONFIGURATION
entities.description: Operating System Configuration refers to making changes to the operating system to harden it against security threats.

entities.name: LIMIT SOFTWARE INSTALLATION
entities.description: Limit Software Installation is a method that restricts users from installing unapproved software to maintain system integrity.

entities.name: RESTRICT FILE AND DIRECTORY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict File and Directory Permissions involves setting access controls to limit who can access certain files and directories.

entities.name: RESTRICT REGISTRY PERMISSIONS
entities.description: Restrict Registry Permissions is a method to control modifications to specific hives or keys in the Windows Registry.

entities.name: AUDIT
entities.description: Audit is a process of reviewing systems and configurations to identify potential security weaknesses.

entities.name: NETWORK SEGMENTATION
entities.description: Network Segmentation is the practice of dividing a network into sections to isolate critical systems and enhance security.

entities.name: FILTER NETWORK TRAFFIC
entities.description: Filter Network Traffic involves using appliances to manage and filter network traffic based on protocols.

entities.name: USER ACCOUNT MANAGEMENT
entities.description: User Account Management is the process of overseeing user accounts and their permissions to ensure security.

entities.name: BEHAVIOR PREVENTION ON ENDPOINT
entities.description: Behavior Prevention on Endpoint is a method to stop suspicious activities on endpoint systems.

entities.name: DISABLE OR REMOVE FEATURE OR PROGRAM
entities.description: Disable or Remove Feature or Program is a method to eliminate unnecessary software that could be exploited.

entities.name: EXECUTION PREVENTION
entities.description: Execution Prevention is a technique to block unauthorized code execution on systems.

entities.name: LIMIT ACCESS TO RESOURCE OVER NETWORK
entities.description: Limit Access to Resource Over Network is a method to restrict access to file shares and remote systems to enhance security.)<|COMPLETE|>("entity"

chunk:
The following content describes information about software. The format of each software's information is as follows:
Software name: ***
Software description: ***
Platforms: ***
These respectively represent the name of the software, a detailed description, and the platforms on which it operates.

Software name: PolyglotDuke
Software description: [PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) is a downloader that has been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least 2013. [PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) has been used to drop [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051).(Citation: ESET Dukes October 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Chrommme
Software description: [Chrommme](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0667) is a backdoor tool written using the Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC) framework that was first reported in June 2021; security researchers noted infrastructure overlaps with [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) malware.(Citation: ESET Gelsemium June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: AsyncRAT
Software description: [AsyncRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1087) is an open-source remote access tool originally available through the NYANxCAT Github repository that has been used in malicious campaigns.(Citation: Morphisec Snip3 May 2021)(Citation: Cisco Operation Layover September 2021)(Citation: Telefonica Snip3 December 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Dridex
Software description: [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) is a prolific banking Trojan that first appeared in 2014. By December 2019, the US Treasury estimated [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) had infected computers in hundreds of banks and financial institutions in over 40 countries, leading to more than $100 million in theft. [Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) was created from the source code of the Bugat banking Trojan (also known as Cridex).(Citation: Dell Dridex Oct 2015)(Citation: Kaspersky Dridex May 2017)(Citation: Treasury EvilCorp Dec 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Power Loader
Software description: [Power Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0177) is modular code sold in the cybercrime market used as a downloader in malware families such as Carberp, Redyms and Gapz. (Citation: MalwareTech Power Loader Aug 2013) (Citation: WeLiveSecurity Gapz and Redyms Mar 2013)
Platforms: None

Software name: Tarrask
Software description: [Tarrask](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1011) is malware that has been used by [HAFNIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0125) since at least August 2021. [Tarrask](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1011) was designed to evade digital defenses and maintain persistence by generating concealed scheduled tasks.(Citation: Tarrask scheduled task)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Stuxnet
Software description: [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was the first publicly reported piece of malware to specifically target industrial control systems devices. [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) is a large and complex piece of malware that utilized multiple different behaviors including multiple zero-day vulnerabilities, a sophisticated Windows rootkit, and network infection routines.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Chien February 2011)(Citation: CISA ICS Advisory ICSA-10-272-01)(Citation: ESET Stuxnet Under the Microscope)(Citation: Langer Stuxnet) [Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) was discovered in 2010, with some components being used as early as November 2008.(Citation: Nicolas Falliere, Liam O Murchu, Eric Chien February 2011) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: WindTail
Software description: [WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) is a macOS surveillance implant used by [Windshift](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0112). [WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) shares code similarities with Hack Back aka KitM OSX.(Citation: SANS Windshift August 2018)(Citation: objective-see windtail1 dec 2018)(Citation: objective-see windtail2 jan 2019)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: Emotet
Software description: [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) is a modular malware variant which is primarily used as a downloader for other malware variants such as [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) and [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483). Emotet first emerged in June 2014 and has been primarily used to target the banking sector. (Citation: Trend Micro Banking Malware Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Octopus
Software description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) is a Windows Trojan written in the Delphi programming language that has been used by [Nomadic Octopus](

entities.name: POLYGLOTDUKE

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber espionage group known for its sophisticated attacks and use of various malware, including PolyglotDuke.

entities.name: CHROMMME

entities.description: Gelsemium is a malware that shares infrastructure with Chrommme, indicating a possible connection between the two.

entities.name: ASYNCRAT
entities.description: AsyncRAT is an open-source remote access tool used in malicious campaigns, originally available on GitHub.

entities.name: DRIDEX
entities.description: Dridex is a banking Trojan that has infected computers in hundreds of banks globally, leading to significant financial theft since its emergence in 2014.

entities.name: POWER LOADER
entities.description: Power Loader is modular code sold in the cybercrime market, used as a downloader in various malware families.

entities.name: TARRASK
entities.description: Tarrask is malware used by HAFNIUM since at least August 2021, designed to evade defenses and maintain persistence.

entities.name: STUXNET

entities.name: WINDTAIL
entities.description: WindTail is a macOS surveillance implant used by Windshift, sharing code similarities with other malware.

entities.name: WINDSHIFT

entities.name: EMOTET

entities.name: BANKING TROJAN
entities.description: Banking Trojan refers to a category of malware, including Dridex, that targets banking credentials and financial information.

chunk:
IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483). Emotet first emerged in June 2014 and has been primarily used to target the banking sector. (Citation: Trend Micro Banking Malware Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Octopus
Software description: [Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340) is a Windows Trojan written in the Delphi programming language that has been used by [Nomadic Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0133) to target government organizations in Central Asia since at least 2014.(Citation: Securelist Octopus Oct 2018)(Citation: Security Affairs DustSquad Oct 2018)(Citation: ESET Nomadic Octopus 2018) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Carbon
Software description: [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) is a sophisticated, second-stage backdoor and framework that can be used to steal sensitive information from victims. [Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) has been selectively used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) to target government and foreign affairs-related organizations in Central Asia.(Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)(Citation: Securelist Turla Oct 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EKANS
Software description: [EKANS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0605) is ransomware variant written in Golang that first appeared in mid-December 2019 and has been used against multiple sectors, including energy, healthcare, and automotive manufacturing, which in some cases resulted in significant operational disruptions. [EKANS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0605) has used a hard-coded kill-list of processes, including some associated with common ICS software platforms (e.g., GE Proficy, Honeywell HMIWeb, etc), similar to those defined in [MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576).(Citation: Dragos EKANS)(Citation: Palo Alto Unit 42 EKANS)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FIVEHANDS
Software description: [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618) is a customized version of [DEATHRANSOM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0616) ransomware written in C++. [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618) has been used since at least 2021, including in Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) campaigns, sometimes along with [SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615).(Citation: FireEye FiveHands April 2021)(Citation: NCC Group Fivehands June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: StoneDrill
Software description: [StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) is wiper malware discovered in destructive campaigns against both Middle Eastern and European targets in association with [APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064).(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: Kaspersky StoneDrill 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ZLib
Software description: [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) is a full-featured backdoor that was used as a second-stage implant during [Operation Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0016) since at least 2014. [ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) is malware and should not be confused with the legitimate compression library from which its name is derived.(Citation: Cylance Dust Storm)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EvilGrab
Software description: [EvilGrab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0152) is a malware family with common reconnaissance capabilities. It has been deployed by [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) via malicious Microsoft Office documents as part of spearphishing campaigns. (Citation: PWC Cloud Hopper Technical Annex April 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BADHATCH
Software description: [BADHATCH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1081) is a backdoor that has been utilized by [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) since at least 2019. [BADHATCH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1081) has been used to target the insurance, retail, technology, and chemical industries in the United States, Canada, South Africa, Panama, and Italy.(Citation: Gigamon BADHATCH Jul 2019)(Citation: BitDefender BADHATCH Mar 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FinFisher
Software description: [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) is a government-grade commercial surveillance spyware reportedly sold exclusively to government agencies for use in targeted and lawful criminal investigations. It is heavily obfuscated and uses multiple anti-analysis techniques. It has other variants including [Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176). (Citation: FinFisher Citation) (Citation: Microsoft SIR Vol 21) (Citation: FireEye FinSpy Sept 2017) (Citation: Securelist BlackOasis Oct 2017) (Citation: Microsoft FinFisher March 2018)
Platforms: Windows, Android

Software name: TajMahal
Software description: [TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) is a

entities.name: ICEDID
entities.description: IcedID is a malware that primarily targets the banking sector and first emerged in June 2014.

entities.name: EMOTET
entities.description: Emotet is a malware that has been used primarily to target the banking sector since its emergence in June 2014.

entities.name: OCTOPUS
entities.description: Octopus is a Windows Trojan written in Delphi, used by Nomadic Octopus to target government organizations in Central Asia since at least 2014.

entities.name: NOMADIC OCTOPUS
entities.description: Nomadic Octopus is a group that utilizes the Octopus Trojan to target government organizations.

entities.name: CARBON
entities.description: Carbon is a sophisticated backdoor and framework used by Turla to steal sensitive information from government and foreign affairs-related organizations in Central Asia.

entities.name: TURLA
entities.description: Turla is a group that employs the Carbon backdoor to target sensitive organizations.

entities.name: EKANS
entities.description: EKANS is a ransomware variant that has been used against multiple sectors, including energy and healthcare, since mid-December 2019.

entities.name: FIVEHANDS
entities.description: FIVEHANDS is a customized ransomware variant used in Ransomware-as-a-Service campaigns since at least 2021.

entities.name: STONEDRILL
entities.description: StoneDrill is wiper malware associated with destructive campaigns against Middle Eastern and European targets.

entities.name: ZLIB
entities.description: ZLib is a backdoor used as a second-stage implant during Operation Dust Storm since at least 2014.

entities.name: EVILGRAB
entities.description: EvilGrab is a malware family with reconnaissance capabilities, deployed via malicious documents in spearphishing campaigns.

entities.name: BADHATCH
entities.description: BADHATCH is a backdoor utilized by FIN8 to target various industries since at least 2019.

entities.name: FIN8
entities.description: FIN8 is a group that has been using BADHATCH to target industries in multiple countries.

entities.name: FINFISHER
entities.description: FinFisher is a government-grade surveillance spyware sold exclusively to government agencies for lawful investigations.

entities.name: TAJMAHAL
entities.description: TajMahal is a sophisticated malware with various capabilities, details of which are not fully disclosed in the text.

entities.name: CENTRAL ASIA
entities.description: Central Asia is the region targeted by Nomadic Octopus and Turla with their respective malware.

entities.name: ENERGY SECTOR
entities.description: The energy sector is one of the multiple sectors targeted by EKANS ransomware.

entities.name: HEALTHCARE SECTOR
entities.description: The healthcare sector is another sector affected by EKANS ransomware attacks.

entities.name: AUTOMOTIVE MANUFACTURING
entities.description: Automotive manufacturing is also targeted by EKANS ransomware, leading to operational disruptions.

entities.name: RANSOMWARE-AS-A-SERVICE
entities.description: Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) is a model in which ransomware like FIVEHANDS is distributed and used in campaigns.

entities.name: MIDDLE EAST
entities.description: The Middle East is one of the regions targeted by StoneDrill malware in destructive campaigns.

entities.name: EUROPE
entities.description: Europe is another region targeted by StoneDrill malware in destructive campaigns.
