Platforms: macOS

Software name: Exaramel for Windows
Software description: [Exaramel for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0343) is a backdoor used for targeting Windows systems. The Linux version is tracked separately under [Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401).(Citation: ESET TeleBots Oct 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: FlawedAmmyy
Software description: [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first seen in early 2016. The code for [FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) was based on leaked source code for a version of Ammyy Admin, a remote access software.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Mar 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RogueRobin
Software description: [RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) is a payload used by [DarkHydrus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079) that has been developed in PowerShell and C#. (Citation: Unit 42 DarkHydrus July 2018)(Citation: Unit42 DarkHydrus Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Netwalker
Software description: [Netwalker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0457) is fileless ransomware written in PowerShell and executed directly in memory.(Citation: TrendMicro Netwalker May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Aria-body
Software description: [Aria-body](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0456) is a custom backdoor that has been used by [Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) since approximately 2017.(Citation: CheckPoint Naikon May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: VERMIN
Software description: [VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) is a remote access tool written in the Microsoft .NET framework. It is mostly composed of original code, but also has some open source code. (Citation: Unit 42 VERMIN Jan 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: TYPEFRAME
Software description: [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) is a remote access tool that has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032). (Citation: US-CERT TYPEFRAME June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KOMPROGO
Software description: [KOMPROGO](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0156) is a signature backdoor used by [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) that is capable of process, file, and registry management. (Citation: FireEye APT32 May 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Woody RAT
Software description:  [Woody RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1065) is a remote access trojan (RAT) that has been used since at least August 2021 against Russian organizations.(Citation: MalwareBytes WoodyRAT Aug 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: XCSSET
Software description: [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) is a macOS modular backdoor that targets Xcode application developers. [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) was first observed in August 2020 and has been used to install a backdoor component, modify browser applications, conduct collection, and provide ransomware-like encryption capabilities.(Citation: trendmicro xcsset xcode project 2020)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: SLOTHFULMEDIA
Software description: [SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) is a remote access Trojan written in C++ that has been used by an unidentified "sophisticated cyber actor" since at least January 2017.(Citation: CISA MAR SLOTHFULMEDIA October 2020)(Citation: Costin Raiu IAmTheKing October 2020) It has been used to target government organizations, defense contractors, universities, and energy companies in Russia, India, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Malaysia, Ukraine, and Eastern Europe.(Citation: USCYBERCOM SLOTHFULMEDIA October 2020)(Citation: Kaspersky IAmTheKing October 2020)  

In October 2020, Kaspersky Labs assessed [SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) is part of an activity cluster it refers to as "IAmTheKing".(Citation: Kaspersky IAmTheKing October 2020) ESET also noted code similarity between [SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) and droppers used by a group it refers to as "PowerPool".(Citation: ESET PowerPool Code October 2020) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Calisto
Software description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) is a macOS Trojan that opens a backdoor on the compromised machine. [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) is believed to have first been developed in

Platforms: Windows

Software name: Calisto
Software description: [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) is a macOS Trojan that opens a backdoor on the compromised machine. [Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) is believed to have first been developed in 2016. (Citation: Securelist Calisto July 2018) (Citation: Symantec Calisto July 2018)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: PoshC2
Software description: [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is an open source remote administration and post-exploitation framework that is publicly available on GitHub. The server-side components of the tool are primarily written in Python, while the implants are written in [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001). Although [PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) is primarily focused on Windows implantation, it does contain a basic Python dropper for Linux/macOS.(Citation: GitHub PoshC2)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: KONNI
Software description: [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) is a remote access tool that security researchers assess has been used by North Korean cyber actors since at least 2014. [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has significant code overlap with the [NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) malware family, and has been linked to several suspected North Korean campaigns targeting political organizations in Russia, East Asia, Europe and the Middle East; there is some evidence potentially linking [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) to [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067).(Citation: Talos Konni May 2017)(Citation: Unit 42 NOKKI Sept 2018)(Citation: Unit 42 Nokki Oct 2018)(Citation: Medium KONNI Jan 2020)(Citation: Malwarebytes Konni Aug 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: EVILNUM
Software description: [EVILNUM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0568) is fully capable backdoor that was first identified in 2018. [EVILNUM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0568) is used by the APT group [Evilnum](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0120) which has the same name.(Citation: ESET EvilNum July 2020)(Citation: Prevailion EvilNum May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Peppy
Software description: [Peppy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0643) is a Python-based remote access Trojan, active since at least 2012, with similarities to [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115).(Citation: Proofpoint Operation Transparent Tribe March 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: IronNetInjector
Software description: [IronNetInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0581) is a [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolchain that utilizes scripts from the open-source IronPython implementation of Python with a .NET injector to drop one or more payloads including [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126).(Citation: Unit 42 IronNetInjector February 2021 )
Platforms: Windows

Software name: GravityRAT
Software description: [GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) is a remote access tool (RAT) and has been in ongoing development since 2016. The actor behind the tool remains unknown, but two usernames have been recovered that link to the author, which are "TheMartian" and "The Invincible." According to the National Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT) of India, the malware has been identified in attacks against organization and entities in India. (Citation: Talos GravityRAT)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BabyShark
Software description: [BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) is a Microsoft Visual Basic (VB) script-based malware family that is believed to be associated with several North Korean campaigns. (Citation: Unit42 BabyShark Feb 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Tomiris
Software description: [Tomiris](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0671) is a backdoor written in Go that continuously queries its C2 server for executables to download and execute on a victim system. It was first reported in September 2021 during an investigation of a successful DNS hijacking campaign against a Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) member. Security researchers assess there are similarities between [Tomiris](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0671) and [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588).(Citation: Kaspersky Tomiris Sep 2021)
Platforms: None

Software name: MarkiRAT
Software description: [MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652) is a remote access Trojan (RAT) compiled with Visual Studio that has been used by [Ferocious Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0137) since at least 2015.(Citation: Kaspersky Ferocious Kitten Jun

political organizations.</data>      <data key="d2">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </node>    <node id="EVILNUM">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">EVILNUM is a backdoor identified in 2018, used by the APT group Evilnum.</data>      <data key="d2">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </node>    <node id="PEPPY">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Peppy is a Python-based remote access Trojan active since at least 2012, with similarities to another malware called Crimson.</data>      <data key="d2">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </node>    <node id="IRONNETINJECTOR">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">IronNetInjector is a toolchain used by Turla that utilizes scripts from IronPython to drop payloads including ComRAT.</data>      <data key="d2">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </node>    <node id="GRAVITYRAT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">GravityRAT is a remote access tool in ongoing development since 2016, linked to attacks against organizations in India.</data>      <data key="d2">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </node>    <node id="BABYSHARK">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">BabyShark is a malware family associated with several North Korean campaigns, written in Microsoft Visual Basic.</data>      <data key="d2">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </node>    <node id="TOMIRIS">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Tomiris is a backdoor written in Go, first reported in 2021 during a DNS hijacking campaign against a CIS member.</data>      <data key="d2">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </node>    <node id="MARKIRAT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">MarkiRAT is a remote access Trojan used by Ferocious Kitten since at least 2015, compiled with Visual Studio.</data>      <data key="d2">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </node>    <node id="FEROCIOUS KITTEN">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Ferocious Kitten is a cyber threat group known for using MarkiRAT in their operations since at least 2015.</data>      <data key="d2">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </node>    <node id="APT37">      <data key="d0" />      <data key="d1" />      <data key="d2">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </node>    <edge source="POWERPOOL" target="CALISTO">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">Calisto is a Trojan that may be associated with the activities of the PowerPool group in cyber threats.</data>      <data key="d5">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </edge>    <edge source="POWERPOOL" target="POSHC2">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">PoshC2 is a framework that could be utilized by groups like PowerPool for remote administration and exploitation.</data>      <data key="d5">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </edge>    <edge source="POWERPOOL" target="KONNI">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">KONNI is a tool used by North Korean actors, which may relate to the activities of PowerPool in the context of cyber threats.</data>      <data key="d5">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </edge>    <edge source="POWERPOOL" target="EVILNUM">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">EVILNUM is a backdoor used by a group with the same name, which may have overlapping interests with PowerPool in cyber activities.</data>      <data key="d5">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </edge>    <edge source="POWERPOOL" target="GRAVITYRAT">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">GravityRAT is a tool linked to attacks against organizations, potentially relevant to the activities of PowerPool.</data>      <data key="d5">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </edge>    <edge source="POWERPOOL" target="BABYSHARK">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">BabyShark is associated with North Korean campaigns, which may intersect with the interests of PowerPool in cyber operations.</data>      <data key="d5">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </edge>    <edge source="POWERPOOL" target="TOMIRIS">      <data key="d3">4.0</data>      <data key="d4">Tomiris is a backdoor that could be relevant to the operations of groups like PowerPool in cyber threats.</data>      <data key="d5">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </edge>    <edge source="POWERPOOL" target="MARKIRAT">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">MarkiRAT is a Trojan used by Ferocious Kitten, which may have connections to the activities of PowerPool.</data>      <data key="d5">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </edge>    <edge source="KONNI" target="APT37">      <data key="d3">8.0</data>      <data key="d4">KONNI is a malware tool associated with the APT37 group, indicating a direct relationship between the tool and the group.</data>      <data key="d5">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </edge>    <edge source="MARKIRAT" target="FEROCIOUS KITTEN">      <data key="d3">1.0</data>      <data key="d4">MarkiRAT is a remote access Trojan used by the Ferocious Kitten group in their cyber operations.</data>      <data key="d5">b0336d557e2431fc5d38b19fd8316faf</data>    </edge>  </graph></graphml>

chunk:
Citation: Kaspersky Tomiris Sep 2021)
Platforms: None

Software name: MarkiRAT
Software description: [MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652) is a remote access Trojan (RAT) compiled with Visual Studio that has been used by [Ferocious Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0137) since at least 2015.(Citation: Kaspersky Ferocious Kitten Jun 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ComRAT
Software description: [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) is a second stage implant suspected of being a descendant of [Agent.btz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0092) and used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010). The first version of [ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) was identified in 2007, but the tool has undergone substantial development for many years since.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug)(Citation: NorthSec 2015 GData Uroburos Tools)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Okrum
Software description: [Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) is a Windows backdoor that has been seen in use since December 2016 with strong links to [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004).(Citation: ESET Okrum July 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Bumblebee
Software description: [Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) is a custom loader written in C++ that has been used by multiple threat actors, including possible initial access brokers, to download and execute additional payloads since at least March 2022. [Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) has been linked to ransomware operations including [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575), Quantum, and Mountlocker and derived its name from the appearance of "bumblebee" in the user-agent.(Citation: Google EXOTIC LILY March 2022)(Citation: Proofpoint Bumblebee April 2022)(Citation: Symantec Bumblebee June 2022)

Platforms: Windows

Software name: RDAT
Software description: [RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495) is a backdoor used by the suspected Iranian threat group [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049). [RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495) was originally identified in 2017 and targeted companies in the telecommunications sector.(Citation: Unit42 RDAT July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CrossRAT
Software description: [CrossRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0235) is a cross platform RAT.
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Software name: Carberp
Software description: [Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) is a credential and information stealing malware that has been active since at least 2009. [Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484)'s source code was leaked online in 2013, and subsequently used as the foundation for the [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) backdoor.(Citation: Trend Micro Carberp February 2014)(Citation: KasperskyCarbanak)(Citation: RSA Carbanak November 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Machete
Software description: [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) is a cyber espionage toolset used by [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0095). It is a Python-based backdoor targeting Windows machines that was first observed in 2010.(Citation: ESET Machete July 2019)(Citation: Securelist Machete Aug 2014)(Citation: 360 Machete Sep 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Penquin
Software description: [Penquin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0587) is a remote access trojan (RAT) with multiple versions used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) to target Linux systems since at least 2014.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla Penquin December 2014)(Citation: Leonardo Turla Penquin May 2020)
Platforms: Linux

Software name: FruitFly
Software description: FruitFly is designed to spy on mac users  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

Software name: CosmicDuke
Software description: [CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) is malware that was used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) from 2010 to 2015. (Citation: F-Secure The Dukes)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Rclone
Software description: [Rclone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1040) is a command line program for syncing files with cloud storage services such as Dropbox, Google Drive, Amazon S3, and MEGA. [Rclone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1040) has been used in a number of ransomware campaigns, including those associated with the [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) and DarkSide Ransomware-as

entities.name: MARKIRAT
entities.description: MarkiRAT is a remote access Trojan (RAT) used by Ferocious Kitten since at least 2015, compiled with Visual Studio and targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: FEROCIOUS KITTEN
entities.description: Ferocious Kitten is a threat group that has utilized the MarkiRAT malware for cyber operations since 2015.

entities.name: COMRAT
entities.description: ComRAT is a second stage implant suspected to be a descendant of Agent.btz, used by the Turla group since 2007, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: TURLA
entities.description: Turla is a cyber threat group known for using various malware, including ComRAT, in sophisticated cyber espionage campaigns.

entities.name: OKRUM
entities.description: Okrum is a Windows backdoor linked to the Ke3chang group, observed in use since December 2016.

entities.name: KE3CHANG
entities.description: Ke3chang is a threat group associated with the Okrum malware, known for its cyber espionage activities.

entities.name: BUMBLEBEE
entities.description: Bumblebee is a custom loader used by multiple threat actors, including ransomware operations, since at least March 2022, targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: CONTIN
entities.description: Conti is a ransomware operation linked to the Bumblebee malware, known for its aggressive tactics in cyber extortion.

entities.name: RDAT
entities.description: RDAT is a backdoor used by the Iranian threat group OilRig, identified in 2017 and targeting telecommunications companies.

entities.name: OILRIG
entities.description: OilRig is a suspected Iranian threat group known for its cyber operations, including the use of RDAT malware.

entities.name: CROSSRAT
entities.description: CrossRAT is a cross-platform remote access Trojan (RAT) that operates on Linux, Windows, and macOS.

entities.name: CARBERP
entities.description: Carberp is a credential and information stealing malware active since at least 2009, with its source code leaked in 2013.

entities.name: MACHETE
entities.description: Machete is a cyber espionage toolset used by the Machete group, targeting Windows machines since 2010.

entities.name: MACHETE GROUP
entities.description: The Machete group is a cyber threat actor known for using the Machete malware for espionage activities.

entities.name: PENQUIN
entities.description: Penquin is a remote access Trojan (RAT) used by Turla to target Linux systems since at least 2014.

entities.name: FRUITFLY
entities.description: FruitFly is malware designed to spy on macOS users, first identified in 2017.

entities.name: COSMICDUKE
entities.description: CosmicDuke is malware used by APT29 from 2010 to 2015, known for its espionage capabilities.

entities.name: APT29
entities.description: APT29 is a cyber threat group known for its sophisticated espionage operations, including the use of CosmicDuke malware.

entities.name: RCLONE
entities.description: Rclone is a command line program for syncing files with cloud storage services, used in various ransomware campaigns.

entities.name: CARBANAK
entities.description: Carbanak is a backdoor that was developed from the leaked source code of Carberp, used in cybercrime activities.

entities.name: DARKSIDE
entities.description: DarkSide is a ransomware group known for its operations that have been linked to various cyber extortion campaigns.

entities.name: QUANTUM
entities.description: Quantum is a ransomware operation that has been associated with the Bumblebee malware in cyber extortion activities.

clone
Software description: [Rclone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1040) is a command line program for syncing files with cloud storage services such as Dropbox, Google Drive, Amazon S3, and MEGA. [Rclone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1040) has been used in a number of ransomware campaigns, including those associated with the [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) and DarkSide Ransomware-as-a-Service operations.(Citation: Rclone)(Citation: Rclone Wars)(Citation: Detecting Rclone)(Citation: DarkSide Ransomware Gang)(Citation: DFIR Conti Bazar Nov 2021)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Software name: gh0st RAT
Software description: [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) is a remote access tool (RAT). The source code is public and it has been used by multiple groups.(Citation: FireEye Hacking Team)(Citation: Arbor Musical Chairs Feb 2018)(Citation: Nccgroup Gh0st April 2018)
Platforms: Windows, macOS

Software name: ConnectWise
Software description: [ConnectWise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0591) is a legitimate remote administration tool that has been used since at least 2016 by threat actors including [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) and [GOLD SOUTHFIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0115) to connect to and conduct lateral movement in target environments.(Citation: Anomali Static Kitten February 2021)(Citation: Trend Micro Muddy Water March 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ObliqueRAT
Software description: [ObliqueRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0644) is a remote access trojan, similar to [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115), that has been in use by [Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) since at least 2020.(Citation: Talos Oblique RAT March 2021)(Citation: Talos Transparent Tribe May 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Pupy
Software description: [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is an open source, cross-platform (Windows, Linux, OSX, Android) remote administration and post-exploitation tool. (Citation: GitHub Pupy) It is written in Python and can be generated as a payload in several different ways (Windows exe, Python file, PowerShell oneliner/file, Linux elf, APK, Rubber Ducky, etc.). (Citation: GitHub Pupy) [Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) is publicly available on GitHub. (Citation: GitHub Pupy)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS, Android

Software name: Volgmer
Software description: [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) is a backdoor Trojan designed to provide covert access to a compromised system. It has been used since at least 2013 to target the government, financial, automotive, and media industries. Its primary delivery mechanism is suspected to be spearphishing. (Citation: US-CERT Volgmer Nov 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Disco
Software description: [Disco](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1088) is a custom implant that has been used by [MoustachedBouncer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1019) since at least 2020 including in campaigns using targeted malicious content injection for initial access and command and control.(Citation: MoustachedBouncer ESET August 2023)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Responder
Software description: Responder is an open source tool used for LLMNR, NBT-NS and MDNS poisoning, with built-in HTTP/SMB/MSSQL/FTP/LDAP rogue authentication server supporting NTLMv1/NTLMv2/LMv2, Extended Security NTLMSSP and Basic HTTP authentication. (Citation: GitHub Responder)
Platforms: None

Software name: ShadowPad
Software description: [ShadowPad](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0596) is a modular backdoor that was first identified in a supply chain compromise of the NetSarang software in mid-July 2017. The malware was originally thought to be exclusively used by [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096), but has since been observed to be used by various Chinese threat activity groups. (Citation: Recorded Future RedEcho Feb 2021)(Citation: Securelist ShadowPad Aug 2017)(Citation: Kaspersky ShadowPad Aug 2017) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: BONDUPDATER
Software description: [BONDUPDATER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0360) is a PowerShell backdoor used by [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049). It was first observed in November 2017 during targeting of a Middle Eastern government organization, and an updated version was observed in August 2018 being used to target a government organization with spearphishing emails.(Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)(Citation: Palo Alto OilRig Sep 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: AppleSeed
Software description: [AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) is a backdoor that has been used by [Kimsuky](https://attack

Platforms: Windows

Software name: AppleSeed
Software description: [AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) is a backdoor that has been used by [Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) to target South Korean government, academic, and commercial  targets since at least 2021.(Citation: Malwarebytes Kimsuky June 2021)
Platforms: Windows, Android

Software name: PyDCrypt
Software description: [PyDCrypt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1032) is malware written in Python designed to deliver [DCSrv](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1033). It has been used by [Moses Staff](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1009) since at least September 2021, with each sample tailored for its intended victim organization.(Citation: Checkpoint MosesStaff Nov 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Crutch
Software description: [Crutch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0538) is a backdoor designed for document theft that has been used by [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) since at least 2015.(Citation: ESET Crutch December 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Proton
Software description: [Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) is a macOS backdoor focusing on data theft and credential access  (Citation: objsee mac malware 2017).
Platforms: macOS

Software name: ThreatNeedle
Software description: [ThreatNeedle](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0665) is a backdoor that has been used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) since at least 2019 to target cryptocurrency, defense, and mobile gaming organizations.  It is considered to be an advanced cluster of [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032)'s Manuscrypt (a.k.a. NukeSped) malware family.(Citation: Kaspersky ThreatNeedle Feb 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SoreFang
Software description: [SoreFang](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0516) is first stage downloader used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) for exfiltration and to load other malware.(Citation: NCSC APT29 July 2020)(Citation: CISA SoreFang July 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ServHelper
Software description: [ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) is a backdoor first observed in late 2018. The backdoor is written in Delphi and is typically delivered as a DLL file.(Citation: Proofpoint TA505 Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Maze
Software description: [Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) ransomware, previously known as "ChaCha", was discovered in May 2019. In addition to encrypting files on victim machines for impact, [Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) operators conduct information stealing campaigns prior to encryption and post the information online to extort affected companies.(Citation: FireEye Maze May 2020)(Citation: McAfee Maze March 2020)(Citation: Sophos Maze VM September 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Action RAT
Software description: [Action RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1028) is a  remote access tool written in Delphi that has been used by [SideCopy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1008) since at least December 2021 against Indian and Afghani government personnel.(Citation: MalwareBytes SideCopy Dec 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Snip3
Software description: [Snip3](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1086) is a sophisticated crypter-as-a-service that has been used since at least 2021 to obfuscate and load numerous strains of malware including [AsyncRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1087), [Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379), [Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331), and [NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198).(Citation: Morphisec Snip3 May 2021)(Citation: Telefonica Snip3 December 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: StrifeWater
Software description: [StrifeWater](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1034) is a remote-access tool that has been used by [Moses Staff](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1009) in the initial stages of their attacks since at least November 2021.(Citation: Cybereason StrifeWater Feb 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Daserf
Software description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) is a backdoor that has been used to spy on and steal from Japanese, South Korean, Russian, Singaporean, and Chinese victims. Researchers have identified versions written in both Visual C and Delphi. (Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017

chunk:
1.(Citation: Cybereason StrifeWater Feb 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Daserf
Software description: [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) is a backdoor that has been used to spy on and steal from Japanese, South Korean, Russian, Singaporean, and Chinese victims. Researchers have identified versions written in both Visual C and Delphi. (Citation: Trend Micro Daserf Nov 2017) (Citation: Secureworks BRONZE BUTLER Oct 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HyperBro
Software description: [HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) is a custom in-memory backdoor used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027).(Citation: Unit42 Emissary Panda May 2019)(Citation: Securelist LuckyMouse June 2018)(Citation: Hacker News LuckyMouse June 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KEYMARBLE
Software description: [KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) is a Trojan that has reportedly been used by the North Korean government. (Citation: US-CERT KEYMARBLE Aug 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Remexi
Software description: [Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) is a Windows-based Trojan that was developed in the C programming language.(Citation: Securelist Remexi Jan 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: yty
Software description: [yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) is a modular, plugin-based malware framework. The components of the framework are written in a variety of programming languages. (Citation: ASERT Donot March 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cannon
Software description: [Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351) is a Trojan with variants written in C# and Delphi. It was first observed in April 2018. (Citation: Unit42 Cannon Nov 2018)(Citation: Unit42 Sofacy Dec 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Ryuk
Software description: [Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) is a ransomware designed to target enterprise environments that has been used in attacks since at least 2018. [Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) shares code similarities with Hermes ransomware.(Citation: CrowdStrike Ryuk January 2019)(Citation: FireEye Ryuk and Trickbot January 2019)(Citation: FireEye FIN6 Apr 2019)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Metamorfo
Software description: [Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) is a Latin-American banking trojan operated by a Brazilian cybercrime group that has been active since at least April 2018. The group focuses on targeting banks and cryptocurrency services in Brazil and Mexico.(Citation: Medium Metamorfo Apr 2020)(Citation: ESET Casbaneiro Oct 2019) 
Platforms: Windows

Software name: PowerSploit
Software description: [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) is an open source, offensive security framework comprised of [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) modules and scripts that perform a wide range of tasks related to penetration testing such as code execution, persistence, bypassing anti-virus, recon, and exfiltration. (Citation: GitHub PowerSploit May 2012) (Citation: PowerShellMagazine PowerSploit July 2014) (Citation: PowerSploit Documentation)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Kivars
Software description: [Kivars](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0437) is a modular remote access tool (RAT), derived from the Bifrost RAT, that was used by [BlackTech](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0098) in a 2010 campaign.(Citation: TrendMicro BlackTech June 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Lucifer
Software description: [Lucifer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0532) is a crypto miner and DDoS hybrid malware that leverages well-known exploits to spread laterally on Windows platforms.(Citation: Unit 42 Lucifer June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: RATANKBA
Software description: [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) is a remote controller tool used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032). [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) has been used in attacks targeting financial institutions in Poland, Mexico, Uruguay, the United Kingdom, and Chile. It was also seen used against organizations related to telecommunications, management consulting, information technology, insurance, aviation, and education. [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) has a graphical user interface to allow the attacker to issue jobs to perform on the infected machines. (Citation: Lazarus RATANKBA) (Citation: RATANKBA)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Gelsemium
Software description: [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) is a modular malware comprised of a dropper (Gelsemine), a loader (Gelsenicine), and main (Gelsevirine) plug-ins written using the Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC)

entities.name: DASERF
entities.description: Daserf is a backdoor software used to spy on and steal from victims in various countries including Japan, South Korea, Russia, Singapore, and China.

entities.name: HYPERBRO
entities.description: HyperBro is a custom in-memory backdoor used by Threat Group-3390.

entities.name: KEYMARBLE
entities.description: KEYMARBLE is a Trojan reportedly used by the North Korean government.

entities.name: REMEXI
entities.description: Remexi is a Windows-based Trojan developed in the C programming language.

entities.name: YTY
entities.description: YTY is a modular, plugin-based malware framework with components written in various programming languages.

entities.name: CANNON
entities.description: Cannon is a Trojan with variants written in C# and Delphi, first observed in April 2018.

entities.name: RYUK
entities.description: Ryuk is a ransomware targeting enterprise environments, used in attacks since at least 2018, sharing code similarities with Hermes ransomware.

entities.name: METAMORFO
entities.description: Metamorfo is a Latin-American banking Trojan operated by a Brazilian cybercrime group targeting banks and cryptocurrency services in Brazil and Mexico.

entities.name: POWERSPOILT
entities.description: PowerSploit is an open-source offensive security framework for penetration testing tasks.

entities.name: KIVARS
entities.description: Kivars is a modular remote access tool (RAT) used by BlackTech in a 2010 campaign.

entities.name: LUCIFER
entities.description: Lucifer is a crypto miner and DDoS hybrid malware that spreads laterally on Windows platforms.

entities.name: RATANKBA
entities.description: RATANKBA is a remote controller tool used by Lazarus Group, targeting financial institutions and various organizations across multiple countries.

entities.name: GELSEMIUM
entities.description: Gelsemium is a modular malware consisting of a dropper, loader, and main plug-ins written using the Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC).

entities.name: NORTH KOREAN GOVERNMENT
entities.description: The North Korean government is associated with the use of KEYMARBLE Trojan for cyber espionage activities.

entities.name: BLACKTECH
entities.description: BlackTech is a cyber threat group that has used the Kivars remote access tool in their campaigns.

entities.name: LAZARUS GROUP
entities.description: Lazarus Group is a well-known cybercriminal organization that utilizes RATANKBA in attacks against various sectors.

entities.name: BRAZILIAN CYBERCRIME GROUP
entities.description: The Brazilian cybercrime group operates the Metamorfo banking Trojan, targeting financial institutions in Brazil and Mexico.

entities.name: C#
entities.description: C# is a programming language used to develop variants of the Cannon Trojan.

entities.name: DELPHI
entities.description: Delphi is a programming language used to develop variants of the Cannon and Daserf Trojans.

entities.name: VISUAL C
entities.description: Visual C is a programming language used to develop versions of the Daserf backdoor.

entities.name: WINDOWS
entities.description: Windows is the operating system platform on which all the mentioned malware operates.

entities.name: C
entities.description: C is a programming language used to develop various malware including Cannon and Remexi.

entities.name: C PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE
entities.description: C programming language is used to develop Remexi Trojan.

entities.name: MODULAR MALWARE FRAMEWORK
entities.description: A modular malware framework refers to the structure of yty, which allows for various components to be used in attacks.

entities.name: RANSOMWARE
entities.description: Ransomware is a type of malware exemplified by Ryuk, designed to extort money from victims.

entities.name: TROJAN
entities.description: Trojan is a type of malware that includes Daserf, KEYMARBLE, and others, used to gain unauthorized access to systems.

entities.name: BANKING TROJAN
entities.description: Banking Trojan refers to malware like Metamorfo that specifically targets banking and financial services.

entities.name: DDOS HYBRID MALWARE
entities.description: DDoS hybrid malware refers to Lucifer, which combines crypto mining and DDoS capabilities.

entities.name: REMOTE ACCESS TOOL
entities.description: Remote access tool refers to malware like Kivars and HyperBro that allows attackers to control infected systems.

entities.name: MODULAR REMOTE ACCESS TOOL
entities.description: Modular remote access tool refers to Kivars, which is derived from the Bifrost RAT.

entities.name: IN-MEMORY BACKDOOR
entities.description: In-memory backdoor refers to HyperBro, which operates without being written to disk.

entities.name: SPYWARE
entities.description: Spyware is a category that includes Daserf, which is used to spy on victims.

entities.name: CYBER ESPIONAGE
entities.description: Cyber espionage is the primary purpose of malware like Daserf and KEYMARBLE.

entities.name: MALWARE
entities.description: Malware is a general term that encompasses all the software mentioned, including Trojans, ransomware, and backdoors.

entities.name: CYBERCRIME
entities.description: Cybercrime refers to the illegal activities conducted using malware like those mentioned in the text.

entities.name: PENETRATION TESTING
entities.description: Penetration testing is a legitimate use case for PowerSploit, which is an offensive security framework.

entities.name: FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS
entities.description: Financial institutions are the primary targets of malware like Ryuk and RATANKBA.

entities.name: ENTERPRISE ENVIRONMENTS
entities.description: Enterprise environments are specifically targeted by ransomware like Ryuk.

entities.name: CRYPTO MINER
entities.description: Crypto miner refers to the functionality of Lucifer, which is designed to mine cryptocurrencies.

entities.name: DROPPER
entities.description: Dropper refers to the component of Gelsemium that installs the malware on the target system.

entities.name: LOADER
entities.description: Loader refers to the component of Gelsemium that loads the main malware payload.

entities.name: MAIN PLUGIN
entities.description: Main plugin refers to the primary operational component of Gelsemium that executes the malicious activities.

entities.name: MODULAR DESIGN
entities.description: Modular design refers to the structure of malware like yty and Gelsemium, allowing for flexible deployment of components.

entities.name: ATTACKS
entities.description: Attacks refer to the malicious activities conducted using the various malware types mentioned.

entities.name: CYBER THREAT GROUP
entities.description: Cyber threat group refers to organizations like BlackTech and Lazarus Group that engage in cybercriminal activities.

entities.name: MALICIOUS INTENT
entities.description: Malicious intent is the underlying purpose of all the malware discussed, aimed at causing harm or theft.

entities.name: EXPLOITS
entities.description: Exploits are vulnerabilities that malware like Lucifer leverages to spread and infect systems.

entities.name: PENETRATION TESTING TASKS
entities.description: Penetration testing tasks are the legitimate activities that PowerSploit is designed to assist with.

entities.name: VARIOUS PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES
entities.description: Various programming languages are used to develop the components of malware like yty.

entities.name: FINANCIAL SECTORS
entities.description: Financial sectors are the primary targets for malware like RATANKBA and Ryuk.

entities.name: CRYPTOCURRENCY SERVICES
entities.description: Cryptocurrency services are targeted by malware like Metamorfo.

entities.name: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY
entities.description: Information technology is one of the sectors targeted by RATANKBA.

entities.name: MANAGEMENT CONSULTING
entities.description: Management consulting is another sector targeted by RATANKBA.

entities.name: EDUCATION
entities.description: Education is one of the sectors targeted by RATANKBA.

entities.name: AVIATION
entities.description: Aviation is one of the sectors targeted by RATANKBA.

id="DASERF">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Daserf is a backdoor software used to spy on and steal from victims in various countries including Japan, South Korea, Russia, Singapore, and China.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="HYPERBRO">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">HyperBro is a custom in-memory backdoor used by Threat Group-3390.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="KEYMARBLE">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">KEYMARBLE is a Trojan reportedly used by the North Korean government.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="REMEXI">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Remexi is a Windows-based Trojan developed in the C programming language.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="YTY">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">YTY is a modular, plugin-based malware framework with components written in various programming languages.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="CANNON">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Cannon is a Trojan with variants written in C# and Delphi, first observed in April 2018.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="RYUK">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Ryuk is a ransomware targeting enterprise environments, used in attacks since at least 2018, sharing code similarities with Hermes ransomware.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="METAMORFO">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Metamorfo is a Latin-American banking Trojan operated by a Brazilian cybercrime group targeting banks and cryptocurrency services in Brazil and Mexico.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="POWERSPOILT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">PowerSploit is an open-source offensive security framework for penetration testing tasks.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="KIVARS">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Kivars is a modular remote access tool (RAT) used by BlackTech in a 2010 campaign.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="LUCIFER">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Lucifer is a crypto miner and DDoS hybrid malware that spreads laterally on Windows platforms.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="RATANKBA">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">RATANKBA is a remote controller tool used by Lazarus Group, targeting financial institutions and various organizations across multiple countries.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="GELSEMIUM">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Gelsemium is a modular malware consisting of a dropper, loader, and main plug-ins written using the Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC).</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="NORTH KOREAN GOVERNMENT">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">The North Korean government is associated with the use of KEYMARBLE Trojan for cyber espionage activities.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="BLACKTECH">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">BlackTech is a cyber threat group that has used the Kivars remote access tool in their campaigns.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="LAZARUS GROUP">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">Lazarus Group is a well-known cybercriminal organization that utilizes RATANKBA in attacks against various sectors.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="BRAZILIAN CYBERCRIME GROUP">      <data key="d0">ORGANIZATION</data>      <data key="d1">The Brazilian cybercrime group operates the Metamorfo banking Trojan, targeting financial institutions in Brazil and Mexico.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="C#">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">C# is a programming language used to develop variants of the Cannon Trojan.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="DELPHI">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Delphi is a programming language used to develop variants of the Cannon and Daserf Trojans.</data>      <data system platform on which all the mentioned malware operates.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="C">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">C is a programming language used to develop various malware including Cannon and Remexi.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="C PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">C programming language is used to develop Remexi Trojan.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="MODULAR MALWARE FRAMEWORK">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">A modular malware framework refers to the structure of yty, which allows for various components key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Trojan is a type of malware that includes Daserf, KEYMARBLE, and others, used to gain unauthorized access to systems.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </node>    <node id="BANKING TROJAN">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Banking Trojan refers to malware like Metamorfo that id="REMOTE ACCESS TOOL">      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Remote access tool refers to malware like Kivars and HyperBro that allows attackers to control infected systems.</data>      <data key="d0">EVENT</data>      <data key="d1">Spyware is a category that includes Daserf, which is used to spy on victims.</data>      <data key="d2">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data> used for cyber espionage and attacks, indicating a relationship in their purpose and usage.</data>      <data key="d6">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </edge>    <edge source="DASERF" target="KEYMARBLE">      <data key="d4">5.0</data>      <data key="d5">Both Daserf and KEYMARBLE are backdoor and Trojan malware types used for cyber espionage, indicating a relationship in their malicious intent.</data>      <data key="d6">052ba78a29b5ea0ded17a9429cdf8d92</data>    </edge>    <edge source="HYPERBRO" target="CANNON">      <data key="d4">5.0</data>      <data key="d5">Both </edge>    <edge source="HYPERBRO" target="KIVARS">      <data key="d4">1.0</data>      <data key="d5">Both Kivars and HyperBro are remote access tools used in cyber attacks, indicating a relationship Platforms: Windows

Software name: Gelsemium
Software description: [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) is a modular malware comprised of a dropper (Gelsemine), a loader (Gelsenicine), and main (Gelsevirine) plug-ins written using the Microsoft Foundation Class (MFC) framework. [Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) has been used by the Gelsemium group since at least 2014.(Citation: ESET Gelsemium June 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ECCENTRICBANDWAGON
Software description: [ECCENTRICBANDWAGON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0593) is a remote access Trojan (RAT) used by North Korean cyber actors that was first identified in August 2020. It is a reconnaissance tool--with keylogging and screen capture functionality--used for information gathering on compromised systems.(Citation: CISA EB Aug 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Dyre
Software description: [Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) is a banking Trojan that has been used for financial gain. 
 (Citation: Symantec Dyre June 2015)(Citation: Malwarebytes Dyreza November 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cobian RAT
Software description: [Cobian RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0338) is a backdoor, remote access tool that has been observed since 2016.(Citation: Zscaler Cobian Aug 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: IcedID
Software description: [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483) is a modular banking malware designed to steal financial information that has been observed in the wild since at least 2017.  [IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483)  has been downloaded by [Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) in multiple campaigns.(Citation: IBM IcedID November 2017)(Citation: Juniper IcedID June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: KGH_SPY
Software description: [KGH_SPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0526) is a modular suite of tools used by [Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) for reconnaissance, information stealing, and backdoor capabilities. [KGH_SPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0526) derived its name from PDB paths and internal names found in samples containing "KGH".(Citation: Cybereason Kimsuky November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: SharpStage
Software description: [SharpStage](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0546) is a .NET malware with backdoor capabilities.(Citation: Cybereason Molerats Dec 2020)(Citation: BleepingComputer Molerats Dec 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: ZxShell
Software description: [ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) is a remote administration tool and backdoor that can be downloaded from the Internet, particularly from Chinese hacker websites. It has been used since at least 2004.(Citation: FireEye APT41 Aug 2019)(Citation: Talos ZxShell Oct 2014)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Hydraq
Software description: [Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) is a data-theft trojan first used by [Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) in the 2009 Google intrusion known as Operation Aurora, though variations of this trojan have been used in more recent campaigns by other Chinese actors, possibly including [APT17](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0025).(Citation: MicroFocus 9002 Aug 2016)(Citation: Symantec Elderwood Sept 2012)(Citation: Symantec Trojan.Hydraq Jan 2010)(Citation: ASERT Seven Pointed Dagger Aug 2015)(Citation: FireEye DeputyDog 9002 November 2013)(Citation: ProofPoint GoT 9002 Aug 2017)(Citation: FireEye Sunshop Campaign May 2013)(Citation: PaloAlto 3102 Sept 2015)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: metaMain
Software description: [metaMain](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1059) is a backdoor used by [Metador](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1013) to maintain long-term access to compromised machines; it has also been used to decrypt [Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) into memory.(Citation: SentinelLabs Metador Sept 2022)(Citation: SentinelLabs Metador Technical Appendix Sept 2022)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: DarkWatchman
Software description: [DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) is a lightweight JavaScript-based remote access tool (RAT) that avoids file operations; it was first observed in November 2021.(Citation: Prevailion DarkWatchman 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: InvisiMole
Software description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S026

entities.name: LAZARUS RATANKBA
entities.description: Lazarus Ratankba is associated with cyber activities and is mentioned in the context of issuing jobs to infected machines.

entities.name: GELSEMIUM
entities.description: Gelsemium is a modular malware used since at least 2014, consisting of a dropper, loader, and main plug-ins, primarily targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: ECCENTRICBANDWAGON
entities.description: ECCENTRICBANDWAGON is a remote access Trojan used by North Korean cyber actors for reconnaissance, keylogging, and screen capture, first identified in August 2020.

entities.name: DYRE
entities.description: Dyre is a banking Trojan used for financial gain, known for its malicious activities targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: COBIAN RAT
entities.description: Cobian RAT is a backdoor remote access tool observed since 2016, primarily targeting Windows platforms.

entities.name: ICEDID
entities.description: IcedID is a modular banking malware designed to steal financial information, observed in the wild since at least 2017, and has been downloaded by Emotet in multiple campaigns.

entities.name: KGH_SPY
entities.description: KGH_SPY is a modular suite of tools used by Kimsuky for reconnaissance, information stealing, and backdoor capabilities.

entities.name: SHARPASTAGE
entities.description: SharpStage is a .NET malware with backdoor capabilities, first observed in late 2020.

entities.name: ZXSHELL
entities.description: ZxShell is a remote administration tool and backdoor available from the Internet, particularly from Chinese hacker websites, used since at least 2004.

entities.name: HYDRAQ
entities.description: Hydraq is a data-theft trojan first used in the 2009 Google intrusion known as Operation Aurora, with variations used in more recent campaigns.

entities.name: METAMAIN
entities.description: metaMain is a backdoor used by Metador to maintain long-term access to compromised machines and decrypt other malware into memory.

entities.name: DARKWATCHMAN
entities.description: DarkWatchman is a lightweight JavaScript-based remote access tool that avoids file operations, first observed in November 2021.

entities.name: INVISIMOLE
entities.description: InvisiMole is a malware that has been used in various cyber operations, details of which are not fully provided in the text.

entities.name: NORTH KOREAN CYBER ACTORS
entities.description: North Korean cyber actors are involved in various cyber activities, including the use of ECCENTRICBANDWAGON for reconnaissance and information gathering.

entities.name: EMOTET
entities.description: Emotet is a notorious malware distribution service that has been involved in various cybercrime activities, including the distribution of IcedID malware.

entities.name: KIMSUKY
entities.description: Kimsuky is a North Korean cyber espionage group known for using KGH_SPY for reconnaissance and information stealing.

entities.name: ELDERWOOD
entities.description: Elderwood is a cyber group known for using the Hydraq trojan in various cyber operations.

entities.name: METADOR
entities.description: Metador is a cyber group that uses metaMain for maintaining long-term access to compromised machines.

chunk:
Windows

Software name: DarkWatchman
Software description: [DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) is a lightweight JavaScript-based remote access tool (RAT) that avoids file operations; it was first observed in November 2021.(Citation: Prevailion DarkWatchman 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: InvisiMole
Software description: [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) is a modular spyware program that has been used by the InvisiMole Group since at least 2013. [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has two backdoor modules called RC2FM and RC2CL that are used to perform post-exploitation activities. It has been discovered on compromised victims in the Ukraine and Russia. [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) infrastructure has been used to download and execute [InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) against a small number of victims.(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2018)(Citation: ESET InvisiMole June 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: certutil
Software description: [certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160) is a command-line utility that can be used to obtain certificate authority information and configure Certificate Services. (Citation: TechNet Certutil)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Smoke Loader
Software description: [Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) is a malicious bot application that can be used to load other malware.
[Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) has been seen in the wild since at least 2011 and has included a number of different payloads. It is notorious for its use of deception and self-protection. It also comes with several plug-ins. (Citation: Malwarebytes SmokeLoader 2016) (Citation: Microsoft Dofoil 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NETWIRE
Software description: [NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) is a publicly available, multiplatform remote administration tool (RAT) that has been used by criminal and APT groups since at least 2012.(Citation: FireEye APT33 Sept 2017)(Citation: McAfee Netwire Mar 2015)(Citation: FireEye APT33 Webinar Sept 2017)
Platforms: Windows, Linux, macOS

Software name: PlugX
Software description: [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) is a remote access tool (RAT) with modular plugins that has been used by multiple threat groups.(Citation: Lastline PlugX Analysis)(Citation: FireEye Clandestine Fox Part 2)(Citation: New DragonOK)(Citation: Dell TG-3390)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HALFBAKED
Software description: [HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) is a malware family consisting of multiple components intended to establish persistence in victim networks. (Citation: FireEye FIN7 April 2017)
Platforms: None

Software name: Crimson
Software description: [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) is a remote access Trojan that has been used by [Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) since at least 2016.(Citation: Proofpoint Operation Transparent Tribe March 2016)(Citation: Kaspersky Transparent Tribe August 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: T9000
Software description: [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) is a backdoor that is a newer variant of the T5000 malware family, also known as Plat1. Its primary function is to gather information about the victim. It has been used in multiple targeted attacks against U.S.-based organizations. (Citation: FireEye admin@338 March 2014) (Citation: Palo Alto T9000 Feb 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Carbanak
Software description: [Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) is a full-featured, remote backdoor used by a group of the same name ([Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008)). It is intended for espionage, data exfiltration, and providing remote access to infected machines. (Citation: Kaspersky Carbanak) (Citation: FireEye CARBANAK June 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POWERSTATS
Software description: [POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) is a PowerShell-based first stage backdoor used by [MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069). (Citation: Unit 42 MuddyWater Nov 2017)
Platforms: Windows

chunk:
second stage malware that has been used by [WIRTE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0090) since at least 2021.(Citation: Kaspersky WIRTE November 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Uroburos
Software description: [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool written in C that has been used by units within Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) associated with the [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) toolset to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has several variants and has undergone nearly constant upgrade since its initial development in 2003 to keep it viable after public disclosures. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) is typically deployed to external-facing nodes on a targeted network and has the ability to leverage additional tools and TTPs to further exploit an internal network. [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) has interoperable implants for Windows, Linux, and macOS, employs a high level of stealth in communications and architecture, and can easily incorporate new or replacement components.(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)
Platforms: Linux, Windows, macOS

Software name: DOGCALL
Software description: [DOGCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0213) is a backdoor used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) that has been used to target South Korean government and military organizations in 2017. It is typically dropped using a Hangul Word Processor (HWP) exploit. (Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Meteor
Software description: [Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) is a wiper that was used against Iranian government organizations, including Iranian Railways, the Ministry of Roads, and Urban Development systems, in July 2021. [Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) is likely a newer version of similar wipers called Stardust and Comet that were reportedly used by a group called "Indra" since at least 2019 against private companies in Syria.(Citation: Check Point Meteor Aug 2021)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cyclops Blink
Software description: [Cyclops Blink](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0687) is a modular malware that has been used in widespread campaigns by [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) since at least 2019 to target Small/Home Office (SOHO) network devices, including WatchGuard and Asus.(Citation: NCSC Cyclops Blink February 2022)(Citation: NCSC CISA Cyclops Blink Advisory February 2022)(Citation: Trend Micro Cyclops Blink March 2022)
Platforms: Network

Software name: Shamoon
Software description: [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) is wiper malware that was first used by an Iranian group known as the "Cutting Sword of Justice" in 2012. Other versions known as Shamoon 2 and Shamoon 3 were observed in 2016 and 2018. [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has also been seen leveraging [RawDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0364) and Filerase to carry out data wiping tasks. Analysis has linked [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) with [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) based on multiple shared artifacts and coding patterns.(Citation: Cylera Kwampirs 2022) The term Shamoon is sometimes used to refer to the group using the malware as well as the malware itself.(Citation: Palo Alto Shamoon Nov 2016)(Citation: Unit 42 Shamoon3 2018)(Citation: Symantec Shamoon 2012)(Citation: FireEye Shamoon Nov 2016)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Valak
Software description: [Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) is a multi-stage modular malware that can function as a standalone information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019 targeting enterprises in the US and Germany.(Citation: Cybereason Valak May 2020)(Citation: Unit 42 Valak July 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: POWRUNER
Software description: [POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) is a PowerShell script that sends and receives commands to and from the C2 server. (Citation: FireEye APT34 Dec 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Cardinal RAT
Software description: [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) is a potentially low volume remote access trojan (RAT) observed since December 2015. [Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) is notable for its unique utilization of uncompiled C# source code and the Microsoft Windows built-in csc.exe compiler.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NKAbuse
Software description: [NKAbuse](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1107) is a Go-based, multi-platform malware abusing NKN (New Kind of Network) technology for

entities.name: WIRTE
entities.description: WIRTE is a cyber espionage group that has been active since at least 2021, known for using sophisticated malware tools for intelligence collection.

entities.name: UROBUROS
entities.description: Uroburos is a sophisticated cyber espionage tool used by Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) to collect intelligence on sensitive targets worldwide, with various upgrades since its initial development in 2003.

entities.name: TURNA
entities.description: Turla is a cyber espionage group associated with the FSB, known for its advanced malware toolset including Uroburos.

entities.name: APT37
entities.description: APT37 is a cyber threat group that has targeted South Korean government and military organizations, known for using the DOGCALL backdoor.

entities.name: DOGCALL
entities.description: DOGCALL is a backdoor malware used by APT37 to exploit vulnerabilities in South Korean government and military organizations.

entities.name: METEOR
entities.description: Meteor is a wiper malware used against Iranian government organizations, including Iranian Railways, in July 2021.

entities.name: CYLOPS BLINK
entities.description: Cyclops Blink is a modular malware used in campaigns by Sandworm Team to target network devices.

entities.name: SHAMOON
entities.description: Shamoon is a wiper malware first used by an Iranian group in 2012, known for its data wiping capabilities and various versions released over the years.

entities.name: VALAK
entities.description: Valak is a multi-stage modular malware that functions as an information stealer or downloader, first observed in 2019.

entities.name: POWRUNER
entities.description: POWRUNER is a PowerShell script used for command and control communication with malware.

entities.name: CARDINAL RAT
entities.description: Cardinal RAT is a remote access trojan observed since December 2015, notable for its unique use of uncompiled C# source code.

entities.name: NKABUSE
entities.description: NKAbuse is a Go-based malware that utilizes NKN technology for its operations.

entities.name: SANDWORM TEAM
entities.description: Sandworm Team is a cyber threat group known for its sophisticated malware campaigns, including Cyclops Blink.

entities.name: SOUTH KOREA
entities.description: South Korea is a country that has been targeted by APT37, particularly its government and military organizations.

entities.name: IRAN
entities.description: Iran is a country that has been targeted by various malware, including Meteor and Shamoon, indicating its significance in cyber warfare.

entities.name: INDRA
entities.description: Indra is a group associated with the use of wiper malware against private companies in Syria, indicating its role in cyber operations.

chunk:
RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) is notable for its unique utilization of uncompiled C# source code and the Microsoft Windows built-in csc.exe compiler.(Citation: PaloAlto CardinalRat Apr 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: NKAbuse
Software description: [NKAbuse](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1107) is a Go-based, multi-platform malware abusing NKN (New Kind of Network) technology for data exchange between peers, functioning as a potent implant, and equipped with both flooder and backdoor capabilities.(Citation: NKAbuse BC)(Citation: NKAbuse SL)
Platforms: Linux, macOS, Windows

Software name: GoldMax
Software description: [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) is a second-stage C2 backdoor written in Go with Windows and Linux variants that are nearly identical in functionality. [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) was discovered in early 2021 during the investigation into the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), and has likely been used by [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) since at least mid-2019. [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) uses multiple defense evasion techniques, including avoiding virtualization execution and masking malicious traffic.(Citation: MSTIC NOBELIUM Mar 2021)(Citation: FireEye SUNSHUTTLE Mar 2021)(Citation: CrowdStrike StellarParticle January 2022)
Platforms: Windows, Linux

Software name: FunnyDream
Software description: [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044) is a backdoor with multiple components that was used during the [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0007) campaign since at least 2019, primarily for execution and exfiltration.(Citation: Bitdefender FunnyDream Campaign November 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: CORALDECK
Software description: [CORALDECK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0212) is an exfiltration tool used by [APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067). (Citation: FireEye APT37 Feb 2018)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: HotCroissant
Software description: [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) is a remote access trojan (RAT) attributed by U.S. government entities to malicious North Korean government cyber activity, tracked collectively as HIDDEN COBRA.(Citation: US-CERT HOTCROISSANT February 2020) [HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) shares numerous code similarities with [Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433).(Citation: Carbon Black HotCroissant April 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Bandook
Software description: [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) is a commercially available RAT, written in Delphi and C++, that has been available since at least 2007. It has been used against government, financial, energy, healthcare, education, IT, and legal organizations in the US, South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia. [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) has been used by [Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070), as well as in a separate campaign referred to as "Operation Manul".(Citation: EFF Manul Aug 2016)(Citation: Lookout Dark Caracal Jan 2018)(Citation: CheckPoint Bandook Nov 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Socksbot
Software description: [Socksbot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0273) is a backdoor that  abuses Socket Secure (SOCKS) proxies. (Citation: TrendMicro Patchwork Dec 2017)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Janicab
Software description: [Janicab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0163) is an OS X trojan that relied on a valid developer ID and oblivious users to install it. (Citation: Janicab)
Platforms: macOS

Software name: REvil
Software description: [REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) is a ransomware family that has been linked to the [GOLD SOUTHFIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0115) group and operated as ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) since at least April 2019. [REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496), which as been used against organizations in the manufacturing, transportation, and electric sectors, is highly configurable and shares code similarities with the GandCrab RaaS.(Citation: Secureworks REvil September 2019)(Citation: Intel 471 REvil March 2020)(Citation: Group IB Ransomware May 2020)
Platforms: Windows

Software name: Sardonic
Software description: [Sardonic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1085) is a backdoor written in C and C++ that is known to be used by [FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061), as early as August 2021 to target a financial institution in the United States. [Sardonic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1085) has a plugin system that can load specially made DLLs and execute their functions.(Citation: Bitdefender Sard

entities.name: RAT
entities.description: RAT is notable for its unique utilization of uncompiled C# source code and the Microsoft Windows built-in csc.exe compiler, functioning on Windows platforms.

entities.name: NKABUSE
entities.description: NKAbuse is a Go-based, multi-platform malware that abuses NKN technology for data exchange, functioning as a potent implant with flooder and backdoor capabilities, available on Linux, macOS, and Windows.

entities.name: GOLDMAX
entities.description: GoldMax is a second-stage C2 backdoor written in Go, discovered during the investigation into the SolarWinds Compromise, and has been used by APT29 since at least mid-2019, available on Windows and Linux.

entities.name: FUNNYDREAM
entities.description: FunnyDream is a backdoor with multiple components used during the FunnyDream campaign since at least 2019, primarily for execution and exfiltration, available on Windows.

entities.name: CORALDECK
entities.description: CORALDECK is an exfiltration tool used by APT37, available on Windows.

entities.name: HOTCROISSANT
entities.description: HotCroissant is a remote access trojan attributed to North Korean government cyber activity, sharing code similarities with Rifdoor, available on Windows.

entities.name: BANDOOK
entities.description: Bandook is a commercially available RAT that has been used against various organizations globally since at least 2007, available on Windows.

entities.name: SOCKSBOT
entities.description: Socksbot is a backdoor that abuses Socket Secure (SOCKS) proxies, available on Windows.

entities.name: JANICAB
entities.description: Janicab is an OS X trojan that relied on a valid developer ID for installation, available on macOS.

entities.name: REVIL
entities.description: REvil is a ransomware family linked to the GOLD SOUTHFIELD group, operating as ransomware-as-a-service since at least April 2019, available on Windows.

entities.name: SARDONIC
entities.description: Sardonic is a backdoor written in C and C++ used by FIN8 to target financial institutions in the United States, available on Windows.

entities.name: SOLARWINDS COMPROMISE
entities.description: The SolarWinds Compromise refers to a significant cyber attack that involved the exploitation of vulnerabilities in the SolarWinds software, during which GoldMax was discovered.

entities.name: DARK CARACAL
entities.description: Dark Caracal is a cyber espionage group that has utilized Bandook malware in its operations.

entities.name: APT37
entities.description: APT37 is a North Korean cyber threat group known for using various malware, including CORALDECK for exfiltration purposes.

entities.name: FUNNYDREAM CAMPAIGN
entities.description: The FunnyDream campaign is an operation during which the FunnyDream backdoor was used for execution and exfiltration since at least 2019.
